post_copy: This is personal, but then again healthcare is personal. Yesterday, I spent 9 hours in the ER at one of Florida's "best" hospitals. As someone who's spent 16 years in healthcare technology, what I witnessed wasn't a tech problem but instead a complete operational failure. My view from the hallway (yes, my entire "room" for the night): - An 80-year-old car accident victim in a neck brace, crying for hours under fluorescent lights, unable to move while staff walked by - A man getting an abdominal ultrasound for internal bleeding with zero privacy - Me, with complex endometriosis and diverticulosis, experiencing severe pain, unable to breathe deeply, walk, or function Oh, and my face? That was me around 10pm, still haven't been given fluids or anything for pain after 5 hours even though my primary complaint was inability to urinate, lower back pain and unable to take a deep breath. This is the face of disappointment and lost hope. Here were some of the observations that made: - "Transport people" shuttling patients between departments for every single test (ultrasound, CT, blood work), then back to our hallway corners - Patient care technicians randomly checking vitals to stay busy - Nurses discussing their "grossest cases" within earshot, someone didn't move from their chairs for hours even though I know they had patients in the hallway - Medical supplies scattered everywhere - The ONE person offering blankets? A transport workerâ€”not clinically trained, just human After 7 hours and every test imaginable, a resident appeared to lecture me about birth control (I've had a hysterectomy) and offered 15 minutes of pain relief with morphine. When a butterfly rash formed across my face, they shrugged it off. My husband runs operations. I consult organizations on their growth strategy. We both see waste and inefficiency for a living. But this wasn't resource scarcity. I counted dozens of staff standing around. This was pure operational incompetence. The nurse told me they'd been treating patients in hallways for a year. They've raised concerns. Administration's response? Convert a neighboring department into another ER hallway "pod" while building a shiny new outpatient tower. We keep throwing technology at healthcare like it's fairy dust. AI this, digital transformation that. But you can't digitize empathy. You can't automate operational basics. And you sure as hell can't tech your way out of administrators who think hallway medicine is acceptable. I woke up today exhausted, still in pain, inflammation out of control with no answersâ€”just deeper cynicism about a system that would rather build monuments than fix foundations. To every healthcare exec reading this: Before you approve another tech vendor or ribbon-cutting, maybe spend 8 hours in your own ER hallway. Not in scrubs with a badgeâ€”as a patient. The transport worker with the blankets understood something your KPIs miss: patients are humans, not throughput metrics.

Iâ€™ve been open about my battle with stage 4 endometriosis. Itâ€™s not glamorous. Itâ€™s not â€œinspiring.â€ Itâ€™s a daily negotiation with pain. Lately, that pain has expanded beyond my pelvic region. Thoracic endo now presses against my diaphragm and lungsâ€”tightness, stabbing pain in my right shoulder, shortness of breath so bad it hurts to breathe deeply. Add arthritis-like pain, chronic fatigue, recurring bladder infections, night sweats, and nausea that feels like food poisoning on repeat. Yesterday, I woke up with one of the worst flare-ups Iâ€™ve had. Normally, I manage with 100mg of tramadol, heat pads, broth, and water. But this time felt different. It hurt to stand. It hurt to sit. My body waved a white flag. I pushed through client calls, then slept 12 hours. Woke up worseâ€”barely able to get out of bed without help. The traditional route (which Iâ€™ve taken more times than I can count) would have been the ER. Instead, I turned to my concierge primary care provider, Rachel Shelley Dhani, MD CAQSM â€”the person I now pay out of pocket because I got tired of being another chart number. I sent her my full medical history, labs, and imagingâ€”all the data thatâ€™s been passed between specialists for years. Hereâ€™s what she found: My MRI from a month ago shows a severe case of diverticulosis. Itâ€™s been sitting there, unaddressed. Missed by every OB, GI, rheumatologist, and thoracic surgeon who has â€œreviewedâ€ my file. Not one caught it. Not one mentioned it. Because each was only looking for their thing. This is the failure of our healthcare system in one patient story. A system built on specialization over integration, transaction over investigation, documentation over discernment. Now, my new care plan actually involves collaborationâ€”distinguishing what belongs to endo vs. diverticulosis, harmonizing treatments, and building a lifestyle plan that treats me, not just my conditions. Thatâ€™s what care should look like. It shouldnâ€™t take privilege, persistence, or concierge care to get it. And this is why millions voted for the promise of MAHAâ€”Make America Healthy Again. Not because we believe in quacks. Not because we reject vaccines or science. But because weâ€™re exhausted. Exhausted by a system thatâ€™s reactive, fragmented, and obsessed with billing codes over human outcomes. If we want to fix healthcare, it has to start with philosophy first. Then policy and incentives. Thenâ€”and only thenâ€”comes the technology. Right now, we keep slapping â€œtech-enabledâ€ and â€œAI-poweredâ€ on processes that are fundamentally broken. All weâ€™re doing is automating dysfunction. This is why I keep working in healthcare. Because the system doesnâ€™t need another app. It needs a new operating model. And yesâ€”Iâ€™ll be fine. God wouldnâ€™t hand me pain I couldnâ€™t handle. I donâ€™t let a little pain get in the way of the impact I plan to makeâ€”in this world, or in healthcare.

Letâ€™s get this out of the way first. Yes, I know posts formatted like this look â€œAI-generated.â€ But LinkedIn â€™s algorithm doesnâ€™t care about your aesthetic preferencesâ€”it cares about readability. Short lines. White space. Rhythm. If you want your content to carry, this is the price. And to the faceless accounts (mostly older men, for some reason) who keep messaging to tell me my writing is â€œawfulâ€ or â€œthe writing of a 7yo," Scroll on. DM harassment over syntax isâ€¦ not the power move you think it is. (Yes, I have no issue sharing screen shots of those that are currently harassing me in the DMs, many of them CEOs nonetheless). Now, onto.... HLTH Inc. The show was glossy, loud, ambitious. But if weâ€™re being honest, itâ€™s having an identity crisis. Who is this conference really for? Investors? Founders chasing Series B? Enterprise vendors? When you try to serve everyone, you serve no one particularly well. AI was everywhereâ€”on booths, on badges, on every other tagline. But the messaging? Generic, soulless, clearly AI-written with zero human edit. Weâ€™re leaning so hard into artificial intelligence that weâ€™re losing authentic intelligence. The sessions I did attend were fantastic. Thoughtful, current, well-moderated. The real shame? Half-empty rooms. It felt like people came to deal, not to learn. But the overwhelming sentiment was that deal's were not happening during the day, but at private events at night. One major highlight: the Womenâ€™s Startup Pitch. Substance over buzzwords. Founders, pitching for 5 minutes to investors "shark tank" style. Talk about pressure. Founders from Veera Health , Incora Health , and Maman Biomedical bringing actual innovation, not vaporware. Let's elevate them more, not in a small room, towards the end of the day, focused on women only. We don't need our own room, we just want a seat at the main table... aka THE MAIN STAGE. Now, the logistics: Healthy eating is fine in theory, but by 4pm, coast-to-coast travelers needed something heartier than quinoa. Fed people are engaged people. Hangry people are not. (Shoutout to the CHIME booth for the Coke Zero mercy rescue and the great discussion on how I can ensure my clients are plugged into the CHIME ecosystem). HLTH used to feel like rebellionâ€”the new kid breaking rules. This year, it felt like it was trying to re-create that energy instead of re-inventing it. Still, I want to acknowledge the HLTH team. Running an event of this scale is brutal, and the production value was exceptional. My critique isnâ€™t about effort, itâ€™s about evolution. The marketâ€™s ripe for something new. Until then, Iâ€™ll keep coming back. Because despite the noise, HLTH still draws the sharpest minds, boldest founders, and some of my favorite people in healthcare. My favorite interactions? Seeing my old colleagues from Cerner, Optum Butterfly, new clients and reading through all of the taglines in my last post ğŸ˜
Well now Iâ€™m determined to find the top 3 taglines at HLTH Inc. today ğŸ˜‚

Every booth at HLTH Inc. sounds exactly the same. "AI-powered platform for healthcare transformation." Cool. So is literally everyone else here. I just walked the expo floor and collected actual taglines: "Reimagining healthcare with generative AI." "AI agents for care delivery across the continuum." "Transform enterprise planning for healthcare organizations." "Intelligent care. Delivered." I literally cannot tell you what any of these companies do. When you're raising capital or chasing partnerships, you think vague sounds visionary. It doesn't. It sounds scared. Scared to be specific. Scared to pick a lane. Scared someone might realize you're not for them. What actually happens when you hide in the sea of sameness: â†’ Nobody remembers you â†’ Nobody knows who to refer you to â†’ Your booth traffic is a parade of "tell me what you do" conversations that go nowhere What if your tagline actually said what you do? Instead of: "AI-powered care coordination platform" Try: "We stop nursing homes from sending people to the ER at 2am" Instead of: "Quality-driven solutions for value-based care" Try: "We help kidney doctors get paid on time by payers who hate them" Instead of: "Transforming patient engagement with intelligent workflows" Try: "We get patients to actually show up for their colonoscopy" The challenge: Describe what you do in 10 words or less. No "coordination." No "quality." No "AI." No "efficiency." Just the problem you solve and who you solve it for. I'll go first: Health Tech House: We get health tech founders unstuck when growth stalls or hasn't started. Your turn. Drop your real tagline in the comments. (And if you can't do it without those four words, your messaging is the problemâ€”not your product.) hashtag # HLTH2025 hashtag # HealthTech hashtag # GoToMarket hashtag # Messaging

I'm a capitalist. I'm also a Christian. Those two things canâ€”and shouldâ€”coexist when we talk about healthcare. Fully expecting to be roasted on this by Matthew Holt . Bring it, friend ğŸ˜ I donâ€™t want anyone turned away from care. But socialized medicine isnâ€™t the answer. Access, affordability, and quality are three different problems that get lumped together under â€œMedicare for All.â€ Itâ€™s intellectually lazy and ignores how the system actually works. When the ACA passed, we pooled the sick and the healthy. It gave access, yes - but made premiums skyrocket for the healthier population. We pretended it wouldnâ€™t. It did. The deception ran deeper. Meaningful Use promised interoperability and connected records. Instead, weâ€™re still faxing. And â€œif you like your plan, you can keep itâ€? Also a lie. Letâ€™s say it out loud: the ACA was one of the worst policies ever forced through. Not because expanding access is wrong - but because execution ignored basic economics, enriched middlemen, and created more problems than it solved. Pharma lobbies Washington for profit. Full stop. PBMs drive up drug prices under â€œadmin overhead.â€ Eliminate them. Point blank, period. Payers shouldn't be dictating care with their Big Brother prior authorization process that is corrupt, unethical, and completely out of control. Physicians are spending hours fighting 97-year-old podiatrists reviewing cardiac procedures. It's not about careâ€”it's about keeping premiums longer to earn time value of money. Physicians need the opportunity to run hospitals again. Remember Physician Hospital Organizations (PHOs)? We need that model backâ€”where clinical expertise drives operations, not MBA administrators optimizing for quarterly earnings. We need representatives who actually know healthcare - not politicians parroting lobbyists. We need to stop pushing for systems from countries one-tenth our size. (Bernie and AOC). And we need to face the truth which is our lifestyle crisis is a healthcare crisis. You canâ€™t innovate your way out of a Big Mac. I believe in a market-driven system that doesnâ€™t leave people to die in the streets. Those arenâ€™t opposing views. That requires: 1ï¸âƒ£ Pricing transparency (Cost Plus Drugs is showing the way) 2ï¸âƒ£ Real competition without middlemen 3ï¸âƒ£ Clinical and AI governance by providers 4ï¸âƒ£ Personal responsibility and more consumer education for preventable disease 5ï¸âƒ£ Policy expertise over partisan noise Our system isnâ€™t capitalism. Itâ€™s crony capitalism - where incumbents write rules, lobbyists write laws, and patients pay the bill. True free-market healthcare would terrify every PBM, payer, and pharma exec in the room. Which is exactly why we should pursue it. This is also exactly why they won't let it happen.

Let's be honest about what HLTH really is. It's not where you close deals with providers or health systems. HLTH Inc. is where health tech comes to see and be seenâ€”by peers, investors, and potential acquirers. It's LinkedIn made physical. And there's nothing wrong with that, as long as we're honest about it. But Sunday's opening sessions exposed the fundamental contradictions healthcare continues to ignore. ğ“ğ¡ğ ğğ¡ğšğ«ğ¦ğš-ğ­ğ¨-ğğğŒ ğ–ğ¡ğ¢ğ©ğ¥ğšğ¬ğ¡ The day opened with pharma's impassioned plea led by Eli Lilly and Company and Rob Lowe (why? nobody knows): we need more people in clinical trials. Only 7% of cancer patients participate, creating massive bottlenecks in bringing life-saving medications to market. Valid. Important. Necessary. Then we immediately pivoted to Mark Cuban systematically eviscerating the entire pharmaceutical supply chainâ€”demolishing the economic model that forces patients on ACA Silver plans to pay $606/month for seven months straight for a drug that costs manufacturers $200 after rebates. The cognitive dissonance was deafening. In one breath, we're asking patients to trust pharma enough to join clinical trials. In the next, we're acknowledging the industry's pricing mechanisms are designed to extract maximum value from those same patients. ğ“ğ¡ğ ğ‚ğğ¥ğğ›ğ«ğ¢ğ­ğ² ğ„ğ±ğ©ğğ«ğ­ ğğ«ğ¨ğ›ğ¥ğğ¦ Mark Cuban is doing important work with Cost Plus Drugs. His transparency model is forcing overdue conversations. But out of every brilliant healthcare operator who lives in the trenches of this industry every single day, HLTH brought on a Gen Z podcaster (not healthcare related)â€”by his own admissionâ€”was studying terminology the night before. Healthcare conferences increasingly platform celebrity voices over subject matter experts. We prize buzz over insight. ğ–ğ¡ğšğ­ ğˆ'ğ¦ ğ€ğœğ­ğ®ğšğ¥ğ¥ğ² ğ‡ğğ«ğ ğ…ğ¨ğ« Despite my cynicism (or maybe because of it), I'm energized: âœ… The AI Sessions: Even though navigating between overlapping sessions in heels is its own cardio workout. âœ… The Conversations: Reconnecting with operators who understand the difference between a buyer persona and an actual buyer. âœ… GTM Strategy: Talking with organizations about their 2026 roadmap. The founders ready to stop guessing and start executing. âœ… Launching Something New (tomorrow): A program for executives who want to master AI in their workflow before mandating company-wide initiatives. HLTH Inc. reflects where healthcare wants to be: innovative, patient-centered, transparent. Sunday's programming revealed where we are: platforming celebrity over expertise, prioritizing optics over outcomes, asking patients to trust systems we openly acknowledge are broken. Are we building innovation for the system we have, or the system we wish existed? Because right now, we're trying to do both. And patients are paying the priceâ€”$606 per month, seven months straight, while we debate which voice gets the microphone.

Ok. Who is traveling to HLTH Inc. today? Whatâ€™s on your â€œwalking through the airportâ€ playlist? Everyone has one. Here is a sample of mine: Lil Wayne Anything Hans Zimmer Taylorâ€™s new album or Rep The NF Chainsmokers Jason Aldean Labrinth Kris Bowers Steve Aoki

"We're using AI for sales emails, marketing copy, even lead scoring... but our pipeline is slower than ever." I asked one question: "Can you tell me, in real-time, which messaging is convertingâ€”and why?" Silence. Six AI tools. Zero visibility into what's actually working. Here's the truth: AI doesn't fix your GTM. It amplifies it. If your GTM engine has friction, AI just helps you fail faster. The real bottlenecks aren't in your tech stack. They're in your handoffs. Map your full GTM flow: â†’ Awareness â†’ Interest (Marketing) â†’ Interest â†’ Engagement (SDR/BDR) â†’ Engagement â†’ Qualified Opp (AE) â†’ Opp â†’ Closed-Won (Sales + SE) â†’ Customer â†’ Activated (CS) At each transition, ask: 1. Where do prospects drop off? 2. Where does context get lost? 3. Where do teams duplicate work? 4. Where do decisions slow down? The fix: AI-generated handoff brief (auto-created from SDR calls, enriched with market intel, one-pager to the AE). Before you add another AI tool, fix the friction points first. Where does your GTM flow actually stall?

Your sales team spends 8 hours per week chasing internal approvals for deals. Doesn't sound that bad, right? Here's the math: â†’ 8 hours/week = 416 hours/year per rep â†’ At $150K OTE = ~$30K in lost selling time per person â†’ For a 10-rep team = $300K/year in hidden friction costs And that's just ONE bottleneck. Most teams have 5-10 of these hiding in plain sight. The problem isn't that you need more AI tools. It's that you haven't found the real inefficiencies yet. Here's what works: Map your 3 most critical workflows (the messy reality, not the idealized version) Ask: Where do handoffs break? Where does context get lost? What requires "tribal knowledge"? Measure the actual cost: time, delays, errors, cognitive drain Then ask: "Could AI handle the repetitive parts so humans focus on judgment?" That's your first automation target.

Your calendar is full. Buyers say they're interested. Your board is patient (for now). Your team believes the deals are coming. You're dying. You just don't know it yet. Pipeline isn't revenue. Interest isn't commitment. Meetings aren't momentum. Real momentum looks nothing like your dashboard. Real momentum means: Deals close when you say they will You forecast with accuracy, not hope Your sales cycle is shrinking, not stretching Buyers give you budget, not "let's circle back in Q2" Your champions have power, not just enthusiasm Here's the test: "If we froze all new outbound today, would we still close deals next quarter?" If the answer is no, you don't have momentum. You have activity. What to do: 1ï¸âƒ£ If a deal has been in your pipeline for 6+ months, it's not a deal. Kill it. 2ï¸âƒ£ Stop counting "opportunities." Start counting real buying signals. Budget approval. Legal engaged. Implementation timeline agreed. 3ï¸âƒ£ Measure time-to-close, not pipeline size. Ask yourself: "What would have to be true for this buyer to sign in the next 30 days?" If you can't answer that, you're not managing a sales process. You're managing hope. Fake momentum kills startups slowly. You burn cash thinking you're close. You hire thinking growth is coming. You wait thinking patience will pay off. Then you run out of runway wondering what happened. Real momentum is uncomfortable. It forces decisions. It demands focus. It exposes what's not working. But it's the only thing that keeps you alive. Stop celebrating activity. Start measuring velocity. ğŸš€

You just spent $50K acquiring a customer. And you handed them to a CS team with no incentive to expand the account. This is the dumbest thing health tech startups do. I've seen companies obsess over optimizing their sales funnelâ€”every email sequence, every demo conversion rate, every objection handlerâ€”while completely ignoring the expansion motion sitting inside their existing accounts. But what about customer success? Why is it an afterthought? Do you know what customer success actually does? Damage control (keep them from churning) Support escalation (fix problems) Relationship maintenance (check-in calls) What CS should actually be: Your highest-ROI sales channel. Think about it: They're already in the account They have trust and access They see usage patterns and adoption gaps They know where expansion opportunities hide They understand the political landscape But most CS teams can't sell because: â˜‘ï¸ They're not incentivized to (flat salary, no commission) â˜‘ï¸ They're not trained to (hired for empathy, not commercial acumen) â˜‘ï¸ They're not measured on it (NRR is a company metric, not a personal one) â˜‘ï¸ They don't have the tools (no expansion playbooks, no pricing authority) The companies that are growing like weeds? Comp CS on net revenue retention, not just renewal rates. Train CS reps to identify and qualify expansion signals. Give CS the authority to propose scope changes without "looping in sales." Build expansion playbooks based on usage milestones and buyer maturity. Real example: A remote patient monitoring company I worked with was stuck at $7M ARR with a 12-month sales cycle. We restructured CS to own expansion. Gave them quotas. Trained them to spot buying signals. Built trigger-based outreach sequences. Within 6 months, 40% of new revenue came from existing accounts. And the CAC? $0. Your existing customers are your lowest-cost path to growth. But only if you treat CS like the revenue engine it should be. Stop thinking "retention." Start thinking "expansion." Your next $1M in ARR is already in your CRM.
Me realizing that I waited wayyyyyyy too long to book my travel to HLTH Inc. next week. Maybe I'll win it back at the craps table? Oh well - who wants to meet up? hashtag # hlth

Why Iâ€™m making the switch to concierge care (and why you might want to, too): Over the weekend, I got to attend my friendâ€™s grand opening for her new concierge medicine practice â€“ House of Valor Concierge â€“ right here in Tampa. And honestly, it couldnâ€™t have come at a better time. I barely have time for a bathroom break, let alone juggling scheduling, referrals, and long drives just to see a doctor. The traditional system wasnâ€™t built for people trying to stay proactive about their health while balancing, well, life. As many of you know, Iâ€™ve been open about my own health journey â€“ and lately, some of those issues have been getting worse and new confusing symptoms have arose, that are leaving even my endo specialist perplexed on where to refer me to next. I need a true partner in my care. Someone who can build a tailored plan, connect the dots across specialists, and actually see me as a whole person. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m partnering with my friend, Dr. Rachel Shelley Dhani, MD CAQSM , and her team at House of Valor. Concierge-level access, functional medicine meets clinical care, and a husband + wife duo that brings it all together â€“ from chiropractic and wellness to peptides, GLP-1 support, and even full executive MRI scans. If youâ€™re in the Tampa area and want healthcare that feels like itâ€™s built around you instead of the other way around, check them out. House of Valor â€“ where modern medicine meets meaningful care. https://lnkd.in/e3A3FS_K

You might hear me talk about a notorious CEO we'll call "Chad." Chad was building "Amazon for healthcare." One app. All healthcare services. Every specialty. Every access point. Consolidated. He told me it would "shut down all the startups." When I started the engagement, his Series A company had 14 customers. And 14 completely different use cases. But Chad was convinced he was building the future of healthcare. Here's the problem: Amazon works because buying paper towels, books, and electronics all require the same behavior: browse, click, buy, ship. Healthcare doesn't work that way. Booking a primary care visit is nothing like coordinating specialty care. Which is nothing like managing chronic disease. Which is nothing like urgent care access. Different buyers. Different workflows. Different pain points. Different decision processes. Chad told himself three lies: Lie #1: "We can serve everyone in healthcare" His "horizontal platform" meant it was for everyone. Except his 14 customers were using it 14 different ways. A 50-bed rural hospital using it for telemedicine. A 15-physician group using it for referral management. An employer using it for navigation. When I told him we needed to pick ONE, he said I "didn't understand the vision and clearly didn't understand how healthcare works." Lie #2: "Our customers all have the same pain point" They didn't. One bought it for virtual care access. One for care coordination. One for price transparency. One because they had a grant to spend. Real product-market fit is when 10 similar buyers buy for the SAME reason, implement the SAME way, and get the SAME outcome. Chad couldn't articulate that. But he could yell at anyone who asked him to. Lie #3: "We'll figure out our ICP once we have more customers" I told Chad: every unfocused customer makes your next sale harder. Your sales team can't build a playbook. Your marketing can't speak to anyone. Your roadmap becomes Frankenstein. Pick ONE customer type. Get 20 wins. Then expand. He told me I was "thinking too small" and "didn't understand platform businesses." Two weeks later, he fired his VP of Sales for missing quota. I terminated the engagement immediately after. Chad thought he was Bezos. Last I heard, Chad's on his fourth VP of Sales in 18 months. Still has 14 customers. Still convinced he's building Amazon. You don't need a bigger vision. You need the RIGHT customers saying yes for the SAME reason. And the humility to listen when someone tells you the truth.

I just reviewed a health tech startup's content library. 47 pieces of content. Zero pipeline contribution. Every single piece answered the question: "How can we look smart?" Not one answered: "How can we help our buyer look smart to THEIR boss?" The following is honestly for my product marketers. Your buyer isn't trying to buy your product. They're trying to survive a budget meeting. Defend an investment to their CFO. Get buy-in from clinical staff who hate change. Prove to their CEO they didn't waste money. Your content should be their ammunition, not your trophy case. Stop writing: "Our AI-powered platform leverages machine learning to optimize clinical workflows..." Start writing: "How to get your CMIO to say yes: The 3 clinical validation questions you must answer" Stop creating: Fluffy thought leadership Product feature lists Self-congratulatory case studies Start creating: Internal business case templates your buyer can customize Stakeholder objection handling guides ROI calculators that survive CFO scrutiny Implementation risk assessments they can show their CIO Competitive analysis that positions YOU as the safe choice The metric that matters isn't downloads. You should take a look at your content library and ask yourself: 1. Did your content get forwarded to someone with budget authority? 2. Did it end up in a slide deck defending the purchase? 3. Did it make your champion look credible and prepared? I've watched deals accelerate by 60 days because we gave a VP of Clinical Operations the exact board presentation they needed. We didn't sell. We equipped. Your marketing team should think like an internal consultant to your buyer. Less "look at us." More "here's how to get this approved." That's how content converts.

Your product might be clinically superior. Your pricing might be better. Your implementation timeline might be faster. And you'll still lose the deal. Why? Because you didn't understand the politics. After 16 years in health tech GTM, I can tell you: logic doesn't close healthcare deals. Politics does. Here's what I mean: - The CMIO loves your solution. But the CFO is protecting the budget for a different initiative that makes them look good to the board. - The VP of Clinical Operations sees the value. But they're 6 months from retirement and won't champion anything that creates work for their team. - The Innovation Director is your internal cheerleader. But they have zero buying authority and don't realize it. The best health tech sales reps I know aren't just good at discovery. They're good at power mapping. They ask: 1ï¸âƒ£ Who actually controls budget allocation? 2ï¸âƒ£ Who has the CEO's ear? 3ï¸âƒ£ What political capital will my champion burn by pushing this forward? 4ï¸âƒ£ Who secretly wants this project to fail, and why? 5ï¸âƒ£ What org politics am I walking into that have nothing to do with my product? You can't logic someone out of a position they didn't logic themselves into. Sometimes the "objection" you're hearing has nothing to do with your product. It's about internal turf wars, legacy vendor relationships, or someone's bonus structure. The founders who master this don't just build better products. They build better stakeholder maps. They understand influence networks. They know when to go around, when to go above, and when to walk away. Healthcare GTM isn't a chess game. It's three-dimensional chess where the board keeps changing and half the pieces have hidden agendas. Learn to play the game, or watch your competition win with an inferior product.

Most teams think they need more AIâ€”when what they really need is to see where their business is bleeding time, context, and consistency. They spend $10K on the latest stack, hand out ChatGPT logins like Halloween candy, and six months later? Nothingâ€™s faster. Just noisier. The problem isnâ€™t AI adoption. Itâ€™s that you automated the wrong things. Before you add another bot, do an AI Audit. Find where work actually stallsâ€”those Slack threads, manual spreadsheets, and 45-minute meetings that couldâ€™ve been a three-line summary.

Your CMO just presented to the board: 450% increase in LinkedIn engagement 89K impressions last quarter 12% click-through rate 2,400 new newsletter subscribers The board nodded. Approved the budget. Three months later, your pipeline is empty and your VP of Sales is asking where the leads are. And that is happening because your VP of sales is expecting marketing to generate all leads and not actually go out there and generate them on their own. Here's what nobody wants to admit: Most health tech marketing in the STARTUP WORLD is run by people who've never closed a healthcare deal (I said most, not all.... don't come for me ğŸ¤£ ) Managed by operators who don't know the difference between a good metric and a vanity metric. So everyone celebrates engagement rates while qualified pipeline sits at zero. The gap: ğŸ”´ Your posts get 10,000 impressionsâ€”but your target buyer didn't see one. ğŸ”´ Your newsletter has 2,400 subscribersâ€”but 2,100 are founders, investors, and consultants with zero buying power. ğŸ”´ Your webinar had 300 registrantsâ€”but the people who showed up already knew they weren't a fit. What actually matters: ğŸŸ¢ Not: "12,000 website visits" But: "47 visits from our ICP, 8 downloaded the business case" ğŸŸ¢ Not: "8% LinkedIn engagement" But: "6 conversations with target buyers who mentioned our content" ğŸŸ¢ Not: "20 pieces published" But: "Sales used 3 in active deals, 2 deals closed citing our content" Real credibility looks like this: - A CMIO forwards your piece to their team because it named their exact problem (how do you know they forwarded the asset? Well you can track that if you're using Foleon ğŸ˜‰ ) - A buyer uses your template in their CFO meetingâ€”and it works. - A champion quotes you when defending the purchase because you gave them language that survives scrutiny. Healthcare buyers don't trust polish. They trust pattern recognition. Write about the IT security review that added 90 days to your cycle. The budget freeze you didn't see coming. The implementation that went sideways. The founders winning right now aren't the ones with the best engagement rates. They're the ones whose buyers say: "This person actually gets it." Credibility compounds. Clicks don't. And when the board asks why pipeline is down, your engagement rate won't save you.
I built my own custom GPT over the weekend to create personal branding content. Thats it, thatâ€™s the post. More to come ğŸ˜‚

Building a life, not just a business. My husband and I have what we call â€œboss weekends.â€ (Yes, I know, millennial alert.) We shut the world out, grab our laptops, and get to workâ€”mapping income goals, travel goals, and the long-term plan for freedom. The kind of freedom that comes from building something togetherâ€”not just wealth, but creative control and flexibility over our own lives. Rome wasnâ€™t built in a day. And neither are businesses with staying power. But being married to an operations expert means every wild idea I dream up gets pressure-tested, systematized, and turned into something that can actually scale. "We sell to healthcare systems with 200+ beds who care about quality metrics and have budget for innovation." Cool. So does everyone else. ğŸ¤¡ That's not an Ideal Customer Profile. That's a LinkedIn filter. Your ICP is complex because they're a human with multiple priorities, politics to navigate, career aspirations, and budgetary limitations. They're not just a "VP of Innovation with a $2M budget." They're someone who: â†’ Just got burned by the last vendor they brought in â†’ Has a boss who says "if it's not broken, don't fix it" â†’ Needs a win before annual reviews kick off â†’ Has to justify every dollar to a CFO who's seen this pitch before The best ICPs I've built include things like: â†’ "Has fired a vendor in our category in the last 12 months" â†’ "CEO has publicly talked about [specific pain point]" â†’ "Currently using duct-tape solutions that cost them $X annually" â†’ "Has hired for [specific role] in the last 6 months" These are signals, not demographics. When you nail this, something magical happens: Your win rate goes up. Your sales cycle goes down. Your team stops wasting time on deals that were never going to close. I once worked with a company that went from 8% win rate to 27% in one quarter. We didn't change the pitch. We changed who we pitched to. Stop selling to everyone. Start selling to someone, with intention.

Policy shapes adoption. Marketing just amplifies it. I've closed deals in health tech for 15 years, and here's the pattern: The startups that scale fastest don't just track their competitive landscape. They track the regulatory and reimbursement landscape like it's their CRM. Smart founders build GTM motions around policy shifts before competitors do. Examples: â¡ï¸ CMS finalizes new reimbursement codes â†’ You launch targeted campaigns to specialties that just became profitable buyers â¡ï¸ FDA updates guidance on software as a medical device â†’ Your positioning shifts 90 days ahead of the herd â¡ï¸ State mandates change around prior auth â†’ You've already built the compliance playbook This isn't academic. This is revenue strategy. While most health tech marketers are chasing "thought leadership," the operators winning deals are asking: âœ… What regulatory change makes our solution 10x easier to buy next quarter? âœ… Which reimbursement shift turns our "nice-to-have" into a "must-have"? âœ… Where is policy creating urgency we can serve? If you're a founder or revenue leader in health tech and you're not reading the Federal Register, CMS transmittals, or state-level regulatory updatesâ€”you're leaving pipeline on the table. Policy isn't a blocker. It's a GTM signal.

Strategy dies without a calendar. Put execution on rails. I've watched too many brilliant GTM strategies collapse in month two. Not because the plan was wrongâ€”because there was no rhythm to execute it. After 15 years scaling teams through IPO, here's the weekly cadence that keeps strategy alive: 1ï¸âƒ£ Monday Morning: Pipeline Reality Check Pull conversation data from Slack, email, calendar invites. Your AI agent surfaces the actual priorities hiding in 147 unread threads. No more "I think we're close on that deal." 2ï¸âƒ£ Wednesday: Content-to-Opportunity Sync What did we ship this week? Which persona assets moved pipeline? AI maps content touches to influenced revenue. Marketing finally gets credit. Sales finally gets useful collateral. 3ï¸âƒ£ Friday: Post-Mortem with Receipts Win/loss review powered by call transcripts and email sentiment. Not someone's memory of what happenedâ€”what actually happened. Agent flags objection patterns and competitive gaps. âš¡ The Magic: Agent-Driven Follow-Ups Between meetings, your AI handles the "just checking in" work. Sends the case study. Books the demo. Reminds you when silence = risk. ğŸ“Š The Dashboard Everyone Signs One source of truth. Pipeline health, content ROI, and next week's priorities. Updated in real-time, not Friday at 4 PM when you're scrambling for board slides. Your GTM doesn't need another strategy deck. It needs a calendar that enforces execution. What's your team's weekly rhythm? Drop it in the commentsâ€”I'm always looking for what's working.

I need to say this loudly for the people in the back: Adding AI to a broken process just gives you a faster way to fail. I'm watching companies drop $50K/month on agentic AI tools. Their conversion rates? Still terrible. Their sales cycle? Still 9 months. Their pipeline? Still a mess. Here's why: AI automates what you TELL it to automate. If your process leaks revenue, AI will leak revenue faster. Before you spend another dollar on AI agents, do this: 1. Map Your Bottlenecks First Where are deals actually dying? (Hint: It's probably not where you think) One RevOps leader I worked with thought it was SDR response time. It was actually contract redlines taking 3 weeks. 2. Automate The Constraint, Not The Noise Don't automate every step. Automate the step that's blocking everything else. â†’ The constraint is your leverage point 3. "Human In The Loop" Checkpoints AI should accelerate decisions, not make them unsupervised. (at least, not yet). Build validation gates at every handoff. Especially where money or reputation is at risk. 4. Redesign Your SLAs Your current SLAs were built for manual processes. If AI can cut response time from 24 hours to 2 hours, your SLA should reflect that. Or your competitors' will. Real example: A Series B company I recently did a 2 week GTM Sprint with implemented agentic AI for lead qualification. First 30 days: Disaster. They automated a qualification process that was already broken. AI was disqualifying good leads and advancing bad ones. After process redesign: Lead-to-opp conversion: +34% Sales cycle: -19 days AE capacity freed up: 8 hours/week Same AI. Different process.

You're not selling software. You're selling organizational change. I learned this the hard way after losing a "sure thing" deal to a health system. They loved the product. ROI was clear. Champion was bought in. But the deal died in procurementâ€”because we didn't map the real buying committee. Here's what no one tells you about enterprise health tech sales: You're asking a hospital, health plan, or enterprise to: â†’ Change clinical workflows â†’ Retrain staff â†’ Integrate into legacy systems that predate smartphones â†’ Get sign-off from IT, compliance, legal, finance, and clinical leadership And all of that has to happen before you hit procurement which can halt the deal on its own. Your product might solve the problem. But that's table stakes. The real question is: Can you navigate the organization well enough to get it implemented? What this actually means: 1. You need to identify 5-8 stakeholders, not just your champion 2. You need to speak clinical language to providers and ROI language to finance 3. You need to understand procurement cycles, capital vs. operating budgets, and compliance reviews 4. You need to build internal champions who can sell for you when you're not in the room The founders who win in health tech aren't just good at selling software or services. They're good at selling change. And they respect how hard that actually is.

Growth is an outcome of discipline, not headcount. One of the most common mistakes I see founders make: They raise a Series A. Get excited. And immediately hire 5 AEs, 2 SDRs, and a VP of Sales. Three quarters later, they've burned $1.2M in comp and have nothing to show for it. Why? Because they confused funding with readiness. You can't hire your way out of an unclear ICP. You can't comp-plan your way past an undefined buyer journey. And you definitely can't scale a sales motion that the founder hasn't closed themselves at least 10 times. Here's what disciplined growth looks like: â†’ Founder closes the first 10-15 deals personally â†’ They document exactly what works: objections, timeline, stakeholders, value props â†’ They hire 1-2 closers and test if the playbook is repeatable â†’ Only then do they scale the team I've seen both sides of this. At one company, we scaled from $7M to $54M in ARRâ€”not by hiring fast, but by building systems that let each rep be twice as productive as the market average. At others, I've watched teams bloat to 12 people before they had a single repeatable motion. Burn rate doubled. Revenue flatlined. If you are a founder and just announced a raise, read this before hiring: - If you can't explain your GTM in 3 sentences, you're not ready to hire for it. - If your founder isn't still closing deals, your team doesn't know what good looks like. - If your CAC is climbing and win rates are dropping, adding headcount will only make it worse. Growth isn't about moving fast. It's about moving right. Discipline first. Scale second.

Stop celebrating bloated forecasts. Start pruning dead deals. Every quarter, I see the same charade: Sales leader presents a $3M pipeline. Board asks about close rates. "We're tracking at 30%," they say confidently. Then the quarter ends. They close $400K. What happened? Half that pipeline was dead on arrival. They just didn't want to admit it. A bloated pipeline is a vanity metric. It makes you feel productive. It makes leadership feel like you're "tracking." But it destroys forecast accuracy, wastes rep time, and kills momentum. After 15 years leading sales and marketing in health tech, I've learned this: A clean pipeline beats a big pipeline. Every time. What ruthless pipeline hygiene looks like: - Stage 1 deals older than 90 days with no meeting? Archive them. - "Waiting on budget" for 3 months with no executive sponsor? Dead. - Champion left the company and no one else engaged? Gone. Your pipeline should scare you a little. If it doesn't, you're lying to yourself about what's actually going to close. Clean house. Move fast. Win more.

All heat, no fire. I've watched founders pour $500K into a sales team before they understand who actually buys their product. The result? Burned cash. Burned team. Burned runway. Here's what I see happen: â†’ They hire 3 SEs after closing 5 pilot deals â†’ They build a pipeline based on "interested" conversations â†’ They forecast revenue using conversion rates from a different market â†’ Six months later: no new logo revenue, team demoralized, board asking hard questions The truth no one wants to hear: - Product-market fit isn't a milestone you celebrate once. It's a hypothesis you validate over and overâ€”across segments, buyer personas, and use cases. And in health tech? It's even harder. Your champion isn't always your economic buyer. Your economic buyer doesn't always mean they control the budget. And the budget holder needs clinical validation, IT approval, and legal sign-off before you see a dime. Before you scale sales, answer these: 1. Can you articulate exactly who closes in <90 days vs. >12 months? 2. Do you know which pain point drives urgency vs. nice-to-have interest? 3. Have you closed the same type of deal 3+ times with a repeatable motion? If not, you're not ready to pour gas. You're ready to get honest. I've scaled revenue from $7M to $112M. The wins didn't come from hiring faster. They came from getting ruthlessly clear on who we served and why they actually bought.

Most health tech marketing is just expensive noise. You've got the one-pagers. The case studies. The webinars no one watches. But here's what actually moves deals: market context. Not what you think matters. What they're already thinking about. â†’ Reimbursement shifts they're losing sleep over â†’ Regulatory changes that just landed in their inbox â†’ Board pressure they can't say out loud Great marketing doesn't educate from scratchâ€”it intercepts the conversation already happening in your buyer's head. The difference? âŒ Content marketing: "Here's why our platform is better." âœ… Market context: "Here's why what you're doing today won't work in Q2." When you lead with insight, not information, you don't compete for attentionâ€”you earn trust before the first call. Ask yourself: Are you creating content your team wants to make, or context your buyer needs to hear? That's the edge.

You can't scale your way out of a weak sales motion. I've watched brilliant founders with incredibly innovative products hit a wallâ€”not because of tech, not because of market fit, but because they skipped GTM fundamentals. They hired fast. Spent big. And burned runway trying to "figure it out" in real time. Here's the pattern: âœ… Raised a strong round âœ… Built an incredible product âœ… Landed the first few logos Then... plateau. Because early traction â‰  repeatable motion. The deals that closed? Founder-led. Relationship-driven. One-off. The pipeline after that? Chaos. No clear ICP. No repeatable messaging. No system to convert interest into revenue. So they hire more AEs. More SDRs. More marketers. And revenue still doesn't moveâ€”because they're scaling people into a process that was never built to scale. GTM discipline isn't sexy. But it's the difference between: âŒ Burning $2M trying to find product-market fit in production âœ… Building a sales engine that compounds with every hire The unsexy reality that many founders ignore or don't know how to solve for: 1. You need to know exactly who buys, why they buy, how they buy, and what it takes to close themâ€”before you scale the team. 2. No amount of headcount fixes weak positioning. 3. No amount of spend fixes unclear value prop. 4. No amount of hustle fixes a sales process built on hope. The best founders treat GTM like engineering: Document it. Test it. Optimize it. Then scale it. If you can't explain your sales motion in 3 sentences, you're not ready to hire for it.

Revenue stalls. Pipeline's thin. CAC is climbing. So the solution? "We need more SDRs. More account execs. More marketers." No. You need better systems. Scaling people into a broken process doesn't fix the problemâ€”it just makes the chaos more expensive. I am calling the bad leaders out here so curious if you have worked with one of these people or are one of these people ğŸ«  Hiring your way out of underperformance is easier than fixing the fundamentals. â†’ It's easier to hire another AE than audit why deals are stalling at demo. â†’ It's easier to add SDRs than fix your ICP targeting. â†’ It's easier to hire a content person than weaponize the insights your sales team already has. The insanely talented operators? They don't immediately scale headcount. They arm their existing team with the tools, clarity, and leverage to do more with less. That could mean: â†’ AI-enabled outreach that's personalized at scale â†’ Self-serve ROI tools that qualify buyers before the call â†’ Sales enablement that doesn't require a human to repeat the same pitch 47 times Growth isn't about doing more. It's about removing what's in the way. Before you add another seat, ask: What's the constraint we're scaling around instead of solving? That's where the leverage is.

All heat, no fire. I've watched dozens of health tech startups make this $10M+ mistake: Hiring 10 reps before nailing 10 customers. Product-market fit in healthcare isn't binary. It's a spectrum: - Clinical fit: Does it solve a real problem? - Economic fit: Does the ROI justify the disruption? - Operational fit: Can they actually implement it? - Political fit: Will stakeholders champion it? Miss any of these, and your expansion will be expensive education. The companies I've helped scale successfully spent 18+ months in "customer development mode" before building a sales machine. They talked to 50+ prospects, closed 10+ pilots, and retained 80%+ before hiring rep #2. Sales scales process, not hope. If you can't explain exactly why your last 10 customers bought, you're not ready to hire your next 10 reps.

Miller-Heiman Challenger SPIN MEDDIC Targeted Account Selling These are all well-known sales methodologies. I have read the books, attended the week long corporate sponsored trainings and have implemented these into Salesforce/Hubspot or pressed my own reps to follow these processes, depending on the company. Recently, I have been helping a few organizations reset their sales process, including building out new stages of the sales cycle, sales enablement, deal flow, building their battlecards, etc.. The above models are tried and true but are they still relevant? We have all heard the saying, in order to get people to buy from you, they have to "know, like and trust" you.. But what if that has now become "prove, like and trust?" Clients want outcomes. They want proof that your product works. And if AI is involved, their skepticism flags are raised. Over the weekend, I started mapping out a new sales methodology... intended for AI-enabled companies that infuses building your proof points, how to gain likeability through personal and professional brand (aka content), as well as validation that trust (hunters) and growing on that trust (farmers). Just thinking out loud here.... In my spare time ğŸ¤” I am starting to build out a new sales methodology, intended for healthcare technology companies, that need up dated strategy, process that your reps will actually adhere to, and more effective ways to measure activity, momentum and roadblocks in your deals. I've watched brilliant health tech founders lose $5M+ deals because they couldn't speak CFO. Your product reduces readmissions by 15%. So what? Your platform improves nurse retention by 20%. So what? Your solution increases patient satisfaction scores by 12%. So what? Healthcare CFOs don't buy clinical outcomes. They buy financial outcomes. The translation: 15% readmission reduction = $2.3M annual penalty avoidance 20% nurse retention improvement = $800K saved in turnover costs 12% patient satisfaction increase = $1.2M HCAHPS bonus eligibility Every health tech sales conversation should answer three questions: How much money does this make us? How much money does this save us? How much risk does this reduce? Clinical value gets you in the room. Financial value gets you the contract. The best health tech companies I've advised have a "CFO translator and talk tracks built" on every sales call.

Most health tech companies treat their CRM like a digital junk drawer. After closing $100M+ in contract value, here's what separates the companies that scale from those that stall: Pipeline hygiene isn't glamorous, but it's everything. The best health tech sales teams I've built follow the 3-2-1 rule: 3 months: If no meaningful movement, archive it 2 weeks: Maximum time between meaningful touchpoints 1 question: "What specific pain are we solving?" I've seen $50M+ companies with 2,000 "opportunities" in their pipeline. Reality? Maybe 200 were real. Clean pipeline = clear forecasting = confident scaling decisions. Dirty pipeline = missed targets = board meetings from hell. Your CRM should tell a story, not house fantasies. When did you last audit your pipeline? The answer usually correlates directly with your close rate.

Strategy starts at the top, not in the marketing department. I've sat in dozens of different company board meetings over 15 years. The fastest-growing health tech companies I've advised all have one thing in common: 1. GTM strategy is agenda item #2 (right after finances). 2. Not buried in the CMO's quarterly update. Not a marketing department afterthought. It's where the CEO, board, and leadership team spend 30+ minutes every meeting dissecting: - Pipeline velocity by segment - CAC trends across channels - Product-market fit metrics - Competitive positioning shifts When GTM is relegated to marketing or sales, you get campaigns and a lot of "noise" documented in your CRM. When GTM is owned by leadership, you get compounding growth. The companies scaling from $10M to $100M ARR? Their CEOs know exactly which customer segments drive profitable growth and which ones drain resources. Strategy starts at the top. Everything else is just execution. What percentage of your last board meeting was spent on GTM strategy?

Outbound is smarter, cheaper, and builds trust faster. I cringe every time I see a health tech startup burning cash on: Trade show booth rentals: $50K for 47 badge scans Lead gen platforms: $200/contact for outdated CIO emails Content syndication: Paying for "engagement" from tire-kickers Here's what actually works in 2025: Strategic outbound built on research. LinkedIn Sales Navigator: $80/month vs. $2,000/month lead platforms Hospital financial reports: Public, free, and full of buying signals Implementation announcements: Perfect timing for competitive displacement Why are so many startups doing this? Bought leads: $200/contact, 0.5% response rate = $40,000/meeting When this is an option? Smart outbound: $0/contact, 8% response rate = $0/meeting Plus, when you do your homework, prospects actually take your calls. The best health tech sales teams I've built never bought a single lead. They earned every conversation.

I've watched 500+ health tech demos over 15 years. The worst ones all make the same mistake: They demo features instead of outcomes. Bad demo: "Here's our medication reconciliation module..." Good demo: "Sarah, your nurses told me they spend 45 minutes per patient manually cross-checking meds between systems. Here's how we cut that to 3 minutes, giving them back 6 hours per shift for actual patient care." Bad demo: "Our AI predicts readmissions..." Good demo: "Tom, you mentioned your 30-day readmission rate hit 18% last quarter, costing you $2.1M in penalties. Here's how we help similar 400-bed systems get below the 15% threshold and recover that revenue." Bad demo: "We integrate with Epic..." Good demo: "Lisa, you said your charge capture team works until 8 PM every night because docs aren't documenting procedures correctly. Here's how we reduce your revenue cycle from 45 days to 28 days while your team goes home on time." The best health tech demos I've delivered follow the Before/During/After structure: Before: "Here's your current state" (with their actual data) During: "Here's what changes" (show the transformation) After: "Here's your new reality" (quantify the impact) Features explain what you built. Outcomes explain why they should buy. Your demo should feel like a preview of their better future, not a tour of your code. The moment they start visualizing their improved state, you've won. What outcome does your demo promise in the first 30 seconds?

Busy â‰  strategic. Motion â‰  progress. After advising 50+ health tech startups, I can spot the difference in five minutes. Companies with GTM strategy: "We target 150-300-bed hospitals in Texas and KS using Cerner or Athena" "Our ICP is health systems spending $500K+ on readmission penalties" "We avoid practices with <10 providers because our CAC exceeds LTV" Companies with GTM activity: "We're targeting provider groups" "We have 17 different personas" "We're launching in all 50 states" Strategy is saying no 100 times to say yes once. Activity is saying yes 100 times and wondering why nothing works. The most successful health tech GTM strategies I've built follow the 1-3-5 rule: 1 primary customer segment 3 key use cases 5 competitor differentiation points Everything else is distraction. If you can't explain your GTM strategy in 60 seconds, you don't have one. You have a to-do list.

An industry begging for disruption: Title & closing services My dadâ€™s estate has been in probate since April. Iâ€™m the administrator. This week, I finally closed on the sale of his property (all cash offer). The attorneys werenâ€™t the problem; my probate attorney and real estate attorney had everything ready. The bottleneck? The title company. - A week of silence leading up to the closing date (which was today). - Multiple errors in the closing sheet caught just 24 hours before signing. - No mention until the eleventh hour that I needed an estate EIN and checking accountâ€”something no first-time executor would magically know. - $500 later for an expedited EIN, three trips to the bank, and I was still the one coordinating the notary. And the kicker? Not a peep from title once everything was signed. This isnâ€™t my first real estate transaction. My husband and I have bought five homes in the last seven years (primary + rentals), and every single transaction has been slowed down by the same choke points: 1. Zero communication. 2. Tools like DocuSign and email exist, but title companies donâ€™t use them effectively. 3. No customer service or sense of urgency. I do not write 4-5 posts a day on Linkedin from scratch. I have help ğŸ˜‰ Yes, I use AI. No, it doesn't do the writing for me. Here is my process ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ I have chatgpt send me 10 ideas every day. But our national sickness isnâ€™t just physicalâ€”itâ€™s systemic. - We have a mental health crisis, and â€œmore accessâ€ alone wonâ€™t solve it. -Weâ€™ve lost the thread on how we define mental health, how we talk about it, and how we actually help people. -We have a crime reform crisis. It's not enough to solve clinical pain, you have to survive the bureaucracy. An AI-powered wound care company had clinicians begging for their solution. Wound healing rates improved 40%. Three procurement realities that blindside founders: 1ï¸âƒ£ Clinical urgency doesn't equal procurement urgency - Life-and-death problems still follow 18-month approval cycles. 2ï¸âƒ£ Champions change, committees endure - Build relationships with the process, not just the people 3ï¸âƒ£ Security and compliance aren't checkbox items - They're the actual decision makers disguised as gatekeepers Smart health tech founders don't just solve clinical problems. They solve procurement problems. They build solutions that slip through bureaucracy like water through cracks. Because the best product in the world means nothing if it can't survive the purchasing committee.

Science impresses. Finance decides. Founders love to lean on clinical validation: the outcomes trial, the published paper, the KOL endorsement. All of it matters, but none of it closes contracts. Hospitals live under financial strain. A product that is clinically exceptional but financially neutral wonâ€™t move. What executives care about is cost reduction, revenue lift, and risk mitigation. Clinical validation gets you in the room. Financial alignment gets you across the finish line. Pair your clinical evidence with a business caseâ€”or youâ€™ll stay in pilot purgatory.

It looks like ammunitionâ€”case studies that stand up to scrutiny, ROI calculators that survive a finance review, and whitepapers that shift executive debate. Stop building content for clicks. Start building content that wins the boardroom.

Clinician nods are not contracts. Too many founders mistake smiles in the demo room for market validation. September is Sepsis Awareness Month. My dear friend Krystal (Cunningham) Anderson lost her life to maternal sepsis in March of 2024â€”a devastating reminder that sepsis is not rare, and it does not discriminate. Every year, sepsis takes 270,000 American lives. 1 in 3 hospital deaths involve sepsis. For new mothers, it is one of the leading causes of preventable maternal mortality. Sepsis often masquerades as something less seriousâ€”flu, infection, or â€œjust not feeling right.â€ But time is everything. Recognizing the signsâ€”confusion, fever, rapid breathing, extreme pain, clammy skinâ€”can be the difference between life and death. I share this in her honor, and for the families who will face this battle today. Awareness isnâ€™t enoughâ€”we need systemic change in how hospitals identify, treat, and prevent sepsis. I fired a 6-figure client earlier this year. Here's why..... Healthcare growth doesn't come from speedâ€”it comes from trust compounded over time. But in healthcare, broken things kill people. And I won't be anywhere near a business model that prioritizes speed over patient safety. My stance on AI in healthcare is clear: it should augment workflows, not replace human judgment. Keep humans in the loop. Create MORE patient-facing opportunities, not fewer. The goal? Less paperwork, higher quality, better outcomes, less burnout. Not shortcuts that put patients at risk. The founders I choose to work with build trust systematically: â†’ Clinical evidence before marketing claims â†’ Pilot programs before platform rollouts â†’ Beta clients before mass outreach â†’ Human oversight in every AI decision Trust is the only currency that scales in this market. You can't hack it, you can't automate it, and you definitely can't rush it. Sometimes the most important business decision is knowing when to say no. Speed kills deals. Trust closes them.

This is happening at startups everywhere. Here's the typical playbook: CEO hires head of sales. CEO has never managed a company before and believes this sales leader should magically have the skillset to set GTM strategy, while selling, while building a team of reps. Unicorn expectations for mortal humans. Head of sales says, "We need more leads and nobody knows who we are." CEO hires VP of marketing. Now the GTM strategy burden shifts to their plate. Problem solved, right? Wrong. That VP of marketing is a magician at setting up systems, measuring MQLs, running events, and creating compelling stories. But GTM strategy? That's a different beast entirely. So now you have two excellent operators pointing fingers at each other while strategy remains dormant. Motion without direction. Activity without alignment. I've lived this from both sidesâ€”as a marketer watching sales blame lead quality, and as a CRO watching marketing optimize vanity metrics. From the outside now, helping startups fix this mess, the pattern is universal. Your GTM lead needs both sales AND marketing experience. Not one or the other. Both. Someone who understands how marketing qualified leads translate to sales qualified opportunities, who knows the difference between campaign attribution and revenue attribution, who can bridge the gap between brand positioning and sales messaging. You need someone who's carried a quota and built demand generation programs. Who's managed sales cycles and marketing funnels. Who speaks both languages fluently because they've lived both realities. Stop expecting your head of sales to be a strategy consultant. Stop assuming your VP marketing understands sales execution. Hire someone who's done both, or accept that your GTM will always be two departments optimizing for different metrics. Strategy isn't something that happens by accident between sales and marketing meetings. It requires intentional leadership from someone who understands the entire revenue machine.

Marketing teams writing content without hearing buyer conversations? I apologize for pointing out this disconnect. Marketing creates "personas" based on assumptions while sales deals with actual humans who say things like "our current system works fine" (translation: change terrifies our IT director) or "we need board approval" (translation: this isn't budgeted and won't be for 18 months). Real buyer language beats polished corporate speak every time. When marketing sits in on 2+ sales calls weekly, magic happens. One of my non-health tech clients saw a 73% uptick in demo requests after marketing heard actual objections and rewrote their messaging around real pain points, not imagined ones. You read that right...... 73%!!!!!! Your personas are probably wrong. Sales calls reveal what buyers actually care aboutâ€”and it's rarely what you think. That clinical workflow improvement you're pushing? They're worried about staff training time. That ROI calculation you perfected? They want to know about implementation timeline. The best marketing teams I work with treat sales calls like customer research labs. They hear the hesitation in a CFO's voice when budget comes up. They catch the excitement when a clinical director talks about patient outcomes. They understand the difference between what buyers say they want and what keeps them up at night. Marketing without sales context is just educated guessing. Sales calls are where assumptions die and real messaging is born.

Your startup celebrates the signed contract. Then ghost-mode kicks in for customer success. Expansion revenue just walked out the door. Here's why â¬‡ The easiest way to spot weak GTM execution? Ask who owns the customer after signature. If you get blank stares or finger-pointing between sales, customer success, and product teams, you've found your revenue leak. ğŸš¨ Post-sale is where margin lives. ğŸš¨ New logos are expensiveâ€”marketing costs, sales cycles, implementation overhead. Expansion revenue is profitable. Existing customers already trust you, know your product, and have budget allocated for growth. Yet most startups treat expansion like an afterthought. Healthcare systems typically buy department by department. Nail one department, prove value, then expand systematically. Cardiology loves your solution? Great. Now nephrology, orthopedics, and the entire enterprise are watching. Screw up implementation or abandon them post-sale, and that expansion pipeline disappears. Unclear ownership creates customer abandonment. Sales tosses them to customer success who lacks technical depth. Customer success escalates to product who doesn't understand the business context. Meanwhile, your championâ€”the person who fought internally to buy your solutionâ€”looks like an idiot because their vendor can't deliver on promises. Retention metrics matter more than acquisition metrics in year 2+. That's when venture funding gets harder and growth efficiency becomes existential. Customer lifetime value beats new logo celebration every time. The best health tech companies I advise treat post-sale like pre-sale. Same urgency, same attention, same executive involvement. Because losing a customer costs more than acquiring one. Who owns your customer's success after the contract signature?

I'm feeling ğŸ”¥ today. Scale requires letting go. My question to founders is: â€œWhy did you hire a VP of Sales and then cut them off from owning strategic accounts?â€ This control-driven approach kills sales teams faster than bad leads or impossible quotas. Tagging accounts as â€œstrategicâ€ and then blocking reps from pursuing them sends one message: we donâ€™t trust you to do the job we hired you for. The ego + fear version: â€œI built this relationship personally,â€œ or "These deals are too important.â€ Translation: Youâ€™re still stuck in founder-led sales mode and need coaching on how to lead your teams better. The greedy version: â€œThey don't deserve to make that big of a commission, we really should adjust our comp plans.â€ Translation: Control matters more than growth and you don't understand the end to end level of effort to get a health tech sales deal across the finish line. The best reps wonâ€™t stay on a bench. They didnâ€™t join to chase warm leads and mid-tier accountsâ€”they came to hunt, solve complex problems, and earn commissions that match. If you block them from big-game deals, theyâ€™ll move to a company that doesnâ€™t. If your â€œstrategicâ€ accounts only close when you personally step in, your GTM isnâ€™t built to scale. Youâ€™ve created a process dependent on youâ€”not a repeatable system your team can run. Healthcare sales requires relationship depth, technical credibility, and institutional knowledge. Train your reps to develop those muscles instead of hoarding the very accounts that would force them to grow. Protecting deals doesnâ€™t build a business. Building a team that can win them consistently does. I repeat.......Scale means letting go. Revenue predictability comes from process, not protection. Your strategic accounts should be proof that your sales team worksâ€”not proof that youâ€™re afraid to pay them.

Sales enablement fails when it prepares reps for demos, not for silence. Most sales training focuses on handling objections. However, buyers don't always object out loud. That requires the ability to read between the lines. So what happens? The deal stalls. The sales leader harasses the rep for next steps. Panic sets in because: 1. Client enthusiasm suddenly drops off 2. The "we need to think about it" with no timeline comes into play 3. The internal champion tops responding to your messages The sales enablement function was a check off the box versus an ongoing training process. In complex B2B sales (especially health tech with its web of stakeholders), silence often means you've lost someone in the buying committee but they're too polite to tell you. Train your team to probe the stall, not just the objection. Instead of "when can we schedule a follow-up," try: "Help me understand what's changed since our last conversation" "What would need to happen for this to move forward?" "Who else has weighed in that I should know about?" "What concerns came up when you discussed this internally?" "Let's walk through a path to implementation so I can ensure we are supporting these efforts on our end the entire way." The best reps don't just handle what prospects say, they handle what they don't say. Sales leaders should be equipped to guide their teams through this process. If they can't or wont, they might not be fit to "lead" people.

Mapping out the prospect progression from cold email to implementation is not a nicetyâ€”it's fundamental GTM strategy. But too many organizations are blind running on their own selling process. They know they need "sales enablement" but can't articulate where deals actually get stuck. They throw tools and training at symptoms instead of diagnosing the real friction points. Your enablement needs should directly map to your buyer's journey: â¡ï¸ Awareness stage = content speaking their language â¡ï¸ Evaluation stage = proof points that matter to their stakeholders â¡ï¸ Decision stage = risk mitigation for the economic buyer â¡ï¸ Implementation stage = change management for the end users This is particularly crucial within health tech. Your clinical champion may adore your solution but if you haven't empowered them to pitch internally to IT, to compliance and to finance. Congrats, you have developed aggravated advocates. Know your journey end to end, then enable accordingly.

Meet Hendrix. Today I had to rush him to the emergency vet. Within minutes of arrival, we were triaged. I sat at his bedside while they assessed him. I filled out intake paperwork on an iPad. The doctor explained exactly what they were doing and why. They ran a FAST exam on the spot. Fifteen minutes later, a nurse brought me a complete care planâ€”line-by-line diagnostics, medications, proceduresâ€”with the price for each, in black and white. â€œHereâ€™s what we recommend. Do you want to move forward with all of it? Or start with certain tests first?â€ I said yes to all. I knew exactly what I was agreeing to. I knew what it would cost. I knew why each item was necessary. And it was my choice. (Turns out he has pancreatitis likely caused by his food The Farmer's Dog ). Im not tagging the company to throw them under the bus, but more to raise awareness that this type of food has a high fat content, and in rare instances, cause pancreatitis. We just happened to be the unlucky ones). Nowâ€¦ letâ€™s imagine the human equivalent. You arrive in a hospital ED. Youâ€™re told to sit in a waiting room for an unknown length of time. Paperworkâ€”half of which is irrelevant to your visitâ€”is shoved in your hands. A nurse takes you back, asks you to repeat your story for the third time. Someone orders tests you donâ€™t understand, for reasons no one explains. No one tells you what they cost. Your insurance company will decide later if they were â€œnecessaryâ€ enough to cover. Weeks later, you get a bill. Or ratherâ€”a stack of them, from multiple providers. Each one a surprise. No one asks if you wanted to start with one test over another. And at no point were you given the dignity of an informed, transparent choice. Weâ€™ve normalized a system where insurance companies dictate care plans after the fact, and patients (or caregivers) get information in fragmentsâ€”too late to make informed decisions. If veterinary medicine can deliver: -Immediate triage -Transparent, line-item pricing before treatment -Clear explanations of each diagnostic and its purpose -The option to proceed, decline, or stage care â€¦why is this impossible in human emergency medicine? Weâ€™ve just built a system that runs on paperwork, not people. Where the â€œcareâ€ part has been quietly stripped from healthcare because it's a constant battle of documentation, justification, necessity, prior authorization and zero transparency for the patient in the middle. We have a bureaucracy-first model where the forms move faster than the patient, and the only thing urgent about the ED is the billing cycle. (BTW, we are home resting now but he's on some heavy pain meds and a a specialty diet going forward.)

Ten years ago, working for one of the top 10 largest health tech companies in the US, I was confident we had our act together. Over 100k employees, billion-dollar revenue, industry-leading solutions; we had personas, pain points, decision criteria, the works. Then I sat through a go-live at a 500-bed hospital system. Hour 7 of watching nurses jump in and out of screens, take notes on a post-it, then a notepad, then back to the cart... I realized: every implementation friction becomes tomorrow's sales objection. â–¶ï¸ What I Learned the Hard Way: That IT director who seemed "difficult" in our sales process? She was protecting her team from yet another vendor promising miracles and delivering migraines. That "excessive" security review? They'd been burned by a previous vendor whose "HIPAA-compliant" solution leaked patient data. The "bureaucratic" procurement process? It exists because when you're dealing with patient lives, you can't afford to get it wrong. point blank. period. end of story. (Founders, stop acting like this isn't a HUGE deal). â–¶ï¸ The Reality Check: Your 30-minute demo doesn't prepare buyers for watching nurses juggle three different workarounds Every "quick integration" that actually takes 10 minutes creates skepticism for life When your "streamlined workflow" forces staff to carry post-it notes between systems, you've lost credibility forever The questions they ask in month 6 of an integration should inform your pitch in week 1 â–¶ï¸ The Fix: Make implementation observation mandatory for your entire growth team (sales, marketing, revops, sales enablement, customer success) team. Im not talking polished demosâ€”the real stuff. The nurses muttering under their breath. The IT admin working weekends to fix what should have "just worked." The physician who stops using your system because it's faster to write things down. â–¶ï¸ The Payoff: When your team understands that every workflow disruption becomes a story prospects will hear, they stop over selling and start reality-checking. When buyers sense you actually understand their worldâ€”the good, bad, and uglyâ€”trust builds faster than any demo ever could. The friction post-sale IS your next pre-sale objection.

Humble brag here: I closed $22K in new business over the last two weeks. One of those weeks I was in Mexico. Not once was a pitch deck used. The secret? I stopped selling and started solving. Here's how trust beats pitch decks every time: â–¶ï¸ KNOW: Before every call, I built a primer on the organization including their current market positioning, who they appear to be targeting, publicly available financial data, recent hires or exits. Walked in knowing their pain before they told me. â–¶ï¸ LIKE: Led with empathy, not features. "I saw your recent partnership announcement with vendor XYZ. Did that create any new leads or website traffic for you?" â–¶ï¸ TRUST: Shared a similar case study with specific metrics: "Here's how I helped startup A reset their GTM position and land their first paid pilot in a market they originally weren't thinking of going after." The Mexico part? Trust was already built. Deals close themselves when buyers believe you actually understand their world. Stop pitching. Start problem-solving.

Your deal just hit procurement. Game over? Not if you planned ahead. Six months of relationship building, gone. They were leveraging this deal for their next raise. Here's your procurement survival kit (build it NOW): âœ… Security attestations - SOC 2, HIPAA, state-specific requirements âœ… Implementation timelines - realistic ones, not sales fantasies âœ… Reference customers - same size, same use case, same compliance needs âœ… Total cost breakdown - including hidden integration costs they always ask about âœ… Risk mitigation plan - what happens when (not if) things go sideways Pro tip: That "boring" compliance meeting you keep pushing off? It's actually your biggest competitive advantage. Most vendors show up empty-handed. Late-stage friction kills good deals. Get ahead of it.

Stop building buyer personas for people who don't exist. I've watched too many health tech startups burn cash on "ideal customer profiles" that were copy and paste from ChatGPT (the formatting gives it away). Meanwhile, real buyersâ€”stressed CFOs watching margins collapse, IT directors drowning in vendor requests, clinicians working 12-hour shiftsâ€”get ignored (Yes, those em dashes are grammatically correct and not written by AI). Here's what actually closes deals in healthcare: â†’ The overwhelmed CMO who needs proof your solution works in 60 days, not 6 months â†’ The procurement director who's been burned by three "AI" vendors that were just fancy if-then statements â†’ The department head whose budget got slashed 15% but patient volume increased 20% Forget the theoretical. Find the frustrated. They're the ones writing checks.
