Most GTM playbooks fail because they were written for a different buyer in a different century. The decision-making map inside a hospital doesn't look like your HubSpot dashboard. As a consultant, I unfortunately get brought in when the well-funded startups flame out because their entire go-to-market strategy was built around "identifying the economic buyer and creating urgency." In healthcare, there is no single economic buyer. There's a consortium of stakeholders who all have veto power. Your SaaS playbook says: 1. Find the decision maker 2. Create urgency 3. Push for quick close 4. Scale with predictable metrics Healthcare reality: âœ… There are 7-12 people involved in every decision âœ… Urgency without consensus creates resistance âœ… "Quick" means 8-14 months âœ… Every deal is a custom snowflake Consider the below framework if you have see growth stall or not hit your numbers as promised to the board. Phase 1: Stakeholder Archaeology Map every person who touches the decision (it's more than you think) Phase 2: Coalition Building Win hearts and minds across departments, not just budget holders Phase 3: Consensus Orchestration Help stakeholders sell each other, not just you Phase 4: Implementation Insurance Show how success is inevitable, not just possible The playbook that works for selling CRM software will get you laughed out of a CMO's office. Healthcare buying isn't broken, your approach is.

In a room full of vendors promising the moon, be the one who delivers next Tuesday. Your biggest competitive advantage in health tech isn't your AI, your algorithms, or your innovation. It's being the one vendor who doesn't overpromise. I've sat through several dozen vendor showcases in my career. However, last month's showcase was not typical (mainly because it was onsite which I rarely get to do anymore). However, the pitches were more of the same. Every company claimed they would "transform healthcare delivery" and "revolutionize patient outcomes." The winner? The company that said: "We'll reduce your lab turnaround time by 23 minutes and save you $47 per test. Here's exactly how." Why underpromise-overdeliver wins in healthcare: â–¶ï¸ Scenario A (The Overpromiser): "Our AI will revolutionize your clinical workflows!" Reality: 6-month implementation, marginal improvements, lots of training and adoption issues with the end users â–¶ï¸ Scenario B (The Realist): "We'll cut your documentation time by 12 minutes per patient encounter" Reality: 8-minute savings achieved in month 2, plus unexpected workflow benefits Guess who gets the renewal? The Reality-Based Messaging Framework: âœ“ Specific metrics instead of broad promises âœ“ "Typically" and "on average" instead of "always" âœ“ Implementation timelines with buffer built in âœ“ Clear scope limitations upfront The counterintuitive result: When you set realistic expectations, buyers trust you with bigger opportunities. In a market drowning in AI vaporware and "revolutionary" claims, being the vendor who tells the truthâ€”even when it's less sexyâ€”is refreshingly sellable. Your credibility is your moat. Protect it fiercely.

However, like healthcare consolidation, where giants absorb hospitals, payers, and tech vendors to control the whole patient journey, AI isnâ€™t just building tools anymore. Itâ€™s going after the platforms that decide how we access information in the first place. The battle isnâ€™t over who builds the smartest AI model. Itâ€™s over who controls the gateway to everything else. Read more about this story here: https://lnkd.in/eb-FjufP

Your champion just butchered your pitch in the hallway to their boss. Congratulationsâ€”you just lost the deal. If your buyer can't repeat your pitch accurately, you're not closing the deal. I watched this play out last year. Their internal champion nailed the messaging in our initial meetings. But when it came time to sell internally, they said: "this will help us reduce readmissions." Great. Reduces readmissions by how much? For which conditions? All-cause or specific diagnoses? Over what timeframe? That vague promise killed a $600K opportunity. The Corporate Telephone Test: After every stakeholder meeting, ask: "How would you explain this to your colleague?" What you'll hear (and why it matters): âŒ "It's complicated, but basically..." âŒ "They do AI innovation for hospitals" âŒ "It's hard to explain, but the demo was amazing" âœ… "It prevents medication errors in real-time" âœ… "It cuts our readmission costs by 15% for all-cause" âœ… "It makes our nurses 20% more efficient" How to build repeatable messaging using my Rule of 3 ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ 1. The Metaphor Method: "It's like spell-check for prescriptions" 2. The Outcome Frame: Start with the result, not the process 3. The Proof Point: One stat they can remember Test it this way: Ask your champion to explain your solution to someone on your product team. If they stumble, your messaging is too complex. In healthcare deals, your champion is your sales team when you're not in the room. Make sure they're armed with words that stick.

"This will revolutionize healthcare" might be the cringiest thing you can say in a hospital C-suite meeting AND the fastest way to expose yourself as completely naive to the healthcare landscape. I was recently approached by a well-known AI company (I'll never tell who) because despite raising massive capital, they're completely stalling out on growth. When I dug into their sales approach, I found the problem immediately: Their entire pitch deck was built around "cutting-edge algorithms" and "breakthrough technology." The response from health systems? Dead silence and/or a polite "we could maybe pilot this with a small cohort, unpaid of course." Here's what hospitals actually hear when you say: "Revolutionary" = "Unproven and dangerous" "First-to-market" = "We're the beta testers" "Cutting-edge AI" = "Liability nightmare" "Transform care delivery" = "Chaos and workflow disruption" What they want to hear instead: âœ“ "Reduces medical errors by 23%" âœ“ "Currently live in 47 similar health systems" âœ“ "Meets all HIPAA and SOC 2 requirements" âœ“ "Integrates without workflow changes" âœ“ "We carry unlimited liability coverage" Don't position yourself as the innovative disruptor. Position yourself as the safe choice that happens to deliver innovation. "We help hospitals reduce readmission risk while maintaining current workflows" beats "We're revolutionizing patient care" every single time.

"Just use the standard deck" might be the four most expensive words in health tech sales and is a good indicator that you lack a strong GTM strategy. I watched a startup burn through 3 quarters of operational spend (between product, marketing and sales) because the CRO kept using the same pitch for everyone. Their CIO wanted technical specs. The CFO wanted ROI data. The Chief medical officer wanted to show risk mitigation, so they combined all of the leadership deck "requests" into one. They got the same 47-slide presentation about "revolutionary care transformation." In multi-stakeholder healthcare deals, templated messaging doesn't just failâ€”it actively works against you. The IT Director hears: "Another vendor who doesn't understand our infrastructure" The CMO hears: "Tech people talking about clinical workflow they've never done" The CFO hears: "Expensive solution to a problem I don't understand" The Chief Nurse hears: "More burden on my already overwhelmed staff" The antidote? Message archaeology: If you are responsible for owning the delivery of the or multiple pitch decks: 1. Interview each stakeholder type separately. 2. Document their exact language for pain points 3. Map their success metrics (they're all different) 4. Build modular content that addresses specific concerns I've seen deals accelerate 40% faster when messaging felt custom-built for each decision maker. Your template might be efficient, but it's not effective. The buyer journey in healthcare isn't linear, so why is your messaging?

I get hired by health tech boards to sit in on CEO presentations (not as a spy, but as an outsider who can spot what's broken before it kills deals). Last month, I watched a $10M ARR company's CEO conduct a zoom call in front of hospital leadership and completely fumble the most basic question: "So what do you actually do?" Forty-seven minutes. That's how long he took to explain their "AI-powered clinical decision support platform with integrated workflow optimization and predictive analytics capabilities that leverages machine learning to enhance care delivery outcomes." Part of my role is to observe and I have grown accustomed (if in person) to take notice to body language, where their eyes are during the presentation and if they are actively listening. The CFO started looking at another screen 3 minutes in. The CMO started checking her phone at minute 8. By minute 15, I was mentally drafting my feedback report. If your value proposition doesn't fit on a Post-It note, it's not a value propâ€”it's a manifesto that's hemorrhaging money. So, I give you the Post-It Test: 1. Write your value prop on a Post-It 2. a 12-year-old understand it? 3. Would your champion be able to repeat it verbatim? 4. Does it start with YOUR problem, not your solution? The winner? "We prevent medication errors before they happen." That's it. Eight words. Every stakeholderâ€”from the floor nurse to the CFOâ€”immediately understood the value. Your complex technology deserves simple messaging. The market is already confused and crowded enough.

Most technology vendors approach hospitals with features. The ones who win start with filings. Hospitals publish more than marketing fluff in their annual reports and community benefit plansâ€”they publish a roadmap. If you know where to look, you can spot: 1. Capital projects that trigger multi-year vendor spend. 2. Service line expansions that require new tech and workflows. 3. Legislative changes that unlock fresh funding streams. 4. Workforce gaps that your solution can solve before they hit critical mass. By the time an RFP drops, youâ€™re already behind. The real advantage comes from reading the tea leaves years before a procurement cycle begins. Please stop pitching into the void. Start mapping your outreach to the next three years of their strategyâ€”straight from their own reports.

Healthcare GTM teams love talking about "transformative innovation" and "revolutionary AI." Meanwhile, their prospects are thinking about compliance audits, implementation timelines, and what happens when the CFO asks for ROI projections. The healthcare buying committee isn't afraid of being left behindâ€”they're afraid of being the cautionary tale their peers whisper about at conferences. Here's how to flip your positioning from aspirational to actionable: Instead of: "AI-powered transformation" Try: "Reduce documentation time by 23% with SOC 2 compliant automation" Instead of: "Next-generation workflow optimization" Try: "Cut patient wait times by 15 minutes using our proven 90-day implementation" Instead of: "Revolutionary patient engagement" Try: "Increase patient satisfaction scores by 18% while reducing staff overtime" Healthcare buyers don't want to be pioneersâ€”they want to be the smart second adopter who learned from everyone else's mistakes. Give them the peer validation, the specific outcomes, and the risk mitigation story they need to look brilliant in the boardroom. Your innovation story might excite investors, but your implementation story closes deals. Healthcare moves slowly by design. Work with that reality, don't fight it.

Most sales training teaches reps to pitch, present, and handle objections with scripted responses. But nobody's teaching them how to sit in the discomfort after a prospect goes quiet, how to use silence as a negotiation tool, or what to do when their perfectly crafted rebuttal lands with a thud. Real enablement happens in the moments between your slides. When a prospect says "We need to think about it," most reps panic and start talking. The trained rep? They count to five, then ask: "What specifically are you thinking about?" and shut up again. Here's what actual enablement looks like: â†’ Role-playing the silence after price objections â†’ Teaching reps when NOT to respond immediately â†’ Building comfort with uncomfortable pauses â†’ Training teams to ask follow-up questions instead of launching into features If your sales team can't navigate a 10-second silence without word-vomiting, your enablement program is incomplete. The best deals happen in the spaces between your talking points.' Stop teaching reps what to say. Start teaching them when to say nothing at all.

LinkedIn is drowning in health tech founders posting the same recycled "insights" about AI transforming healthcare. Your thought leadership sounds like everyone else's thought leadership. Here's how to actually stand out: - Stop Writing About What Healthcare "Should" Do - Everyone knows healthcare needs to modernize. Everyone agrees interoperability is important. These aren't insights - they're platitudes. Start Writing About What You Actually See: "I watched a nurse spend 23 minutes documenting a 5-minute patient interaction. Here's what's broken..." "Three health systems told me the same lie about their 'digital transformation.' Here's what they really mean..." "Your AI vendor just promised 99% accuracy. Here's the one question that exposes if they're lying..." Templates That Actually Work: 1. The Reality Check: "Everyone says [popular belief]. Here's what actually happens when you try to implement it..." 2. The Behind-the-Scenes: "Last week I sat in a CMIO meeting where they killed a $2M project. Here's why..." 3. The Uncomfortable Truth: "Health tech founders love talking about [trendy topic]. But here's what buyers actually care about..." 4. The Pattern Recognition: "I've now seen 47 health systems make this same mistake. Here's how to avoid it..." Stop trying to sound smart. Start being useful. Share the messy reality behind the polished case studies. Call out the industry BS that everyone's too polite to mention. Tell stories about deals that failed and why. Your personal brand should feel like insider intelligence, not press release recycling. Be the person who says what everyone's thinking but no one's willing to write. The healthcare industry has enough cheerleaders. It needs more truth-tellers. hashtag # personalbrand hashtag # brandawareness hashtag # thoughtleadership hashtag # founders hashtag # branding

Key highlights: -60+ companies pledged collaboration for Q1 2026 delivery -New "CMS Aligned Networks" for seamless data sharing -AI-powered tools for diabetes management and symptom checking -Digital identity solutions to eliminate password juggling across healthcare sites Hospital Payment Reform: The proposed 2026 Hospital Outpatient Payment System rule introduces patient-focused changes: -Site-neutral payments to reduce location-based cost penalties -Real pricing transparency (not estimates) from hospitals -Enhanced safety standards - lowest quartile hospitals lose 5-star eligibility -Projected $11B in savings over 10 years After decades of fragmented systems and hidden costs, we're finally seeing concrete steps toward the healthcare transparency and interoperability patients deserve at the federal level. If you can't explain why your prospect needs to solve this problem this quarter, you don't have urgency - you have a nice-to-have wrapped in good intentions. Health systems are drowning in "innovative solutions." Your AI-powered whatever joins a line behind 47 other "game-changing" technologies that all promise to transform healthcare. The winners aren't the best products - they're the ones that create genuine urgency. Here's how to build "Why Now?" into your messaging: - External Pressure: "CMS is changing reimbursement rules in January. Health systems that don't improve their quality metrics by Q4 face $2M+ in penalties." - Internal Catalyst: "Your current system just failed its security audit. You have 90 days to implement new controls or risk losing your enterprise clients." - Competitive Threat: "Regional competitors are already using this technology to capture market share. Every month you wait, they're stealing physicians who prefer modern workflows." - Resource Reality: "Your nurses are burning out at record rates. Exit interviews show workflow inefficiency as the #2 reason they're leaving. You can't hire fast enough to replace them." If your "Why Now?" is "Healthcare needs to modernize," you're going to lose to someone whose "Why Now?" is "Your competitor just announced they're implementing this exact solution and they're actively recruiting your best specialists." Urgency isn't manufactured - it's discovered. Your job is finding the pressure point that makes waiting more expensive than acting. hashtag # GTM hashtag # outcomes hashtag # valueselling hashtag # salesenablement hashtag # strategicselling

"John thinks the deal will close next month because the customer seemed really engaged in the demo." This isn't forecasting. This is wishful thinking with a spreadsheet. Real pipeline reviews don't rely on feelings - they rely on evidence: Instead of: "They love the product" Ask: "What specific business case did they articulate? Who else needs to approve this? What's their procurement timeline?" Instead of: "It's a great fit" Ask: "What exact pain point does this solve? How are they measuring success? What happens if they do nothing?" Instead of: "We have good momentum" Ask: "What specific next step did they commit to? Who introduced us to the next stakeholder? When is their budget cycle?" Here's the framework that actually works: 1. Qualification: Can they buy? (Budget, authority, timeline) 2. Discovery: What's broken? (Specific pain, cost of status quo) 3. Solution: Why us? (Differentiated value, proof points) 4. Validation: Will they buy? (Champion identified, procurement mapped) Each stage requires specific evidence, not opinions. "They seemed interested" isn't evidence. "They introduced us to their CFO and scheduled a budget discussion" is evidence. Stop treating pipeline reviews like group therapy. Start treating them like diagnostic tools that tell you exactly where deals are stuck and what to do about it. hashtag # GTM hashtag # salesenablement hashtag # sales hashtag # growth hashtag # growthhacking

You can't scale what you can't handle yourself. I've watched founders hire their first sales rep, hand them a pitch deck, and wonder why deals stall. You never figured out how to overcome the basic objections that kill 80% of health tech deals. If you can't confidently handle these three, you're not ready to hire anyone: Objection 1: "We don't have budget" Your response better include specific ROI timelines, budget cycle timing, and alternative funding sources (quality improvement funds, IT infrastructure budgets, grant opportunities). If you're just saying "Let's find budget," you're dead. Objection 2: "Our IT/security team will never approve this" You need the exact security documentation, integration timeline, and success stories from similar health systems. Plus the contact info for your champion at another hospital who can speak to their IT team directly. Objection 3: "We're happy with our current solution" This means you didn't do discovery. You need a framework for uncovering hidden dissatisfaction, questions that reveal workflow pain, and competitive intelligence that shows gaps in their current approach. Practice these until they're automatic. Record yourself. Role-play with someone who'll be brutally honest. Because when you hire that first sales rep, they're going to get these objections on day one. The founders who scale successfully aren't the ones with the best products - they're the ones who've battle-tested every response before they put someone else in the hot seat. hashtag # founders hashtag # healthtech hashtag # GTM hashtag # healthcareinnovation

I had a few people ask what exactly will be in my upcoming launch of The AI Course. After getting through the basics, learning how to create valuable prompts and setting up a few automations, we dig into applying AI for complex problems..such as risk evaluations for vendor selection. (dry, tedious, but necessary). Day 5 - Your AI Strategy Partner: I teach you how to build an E2E Risk Assessment and Mitigation Plan when completing diligence on a technology vendor. Reverse engineer this process if you are a vendor to help elevate your company in the rankings when being dragged through and RFP. We start with the following prompt: "Conduct comprehensive risk analysis for [initiative/decision]. Consider: 1. Strategic risks (market, competition, technology) 2. Operational risks (execution, capacity, quality) 3. Financial risks (cost, revenue, cash flow) 4. People risks (talent, culture, leadership) 5. External risks (regulatory, economic, geopolitical) 6. Reputation risks (brand, relationships, trust) For each risk, identify and define the following: -Probability (High/Medium/Low) -Impact (Critical/Major/Minor) -Early warning indicators -Mitigation strategies -Contingency plans The output should presented as risk matrix with action priorities." From there, we continue to iterate and end the conversation with an asset including a dashboard showing our results comparing all vendors, executive summary and guidance for vendor selection. I've spent months building content in this course to where each day compounds on the next. I'll keep sharing previews to get your feedback before launch. The goal? That 47-slide deck about your technology isn't sales enablement. It's a marketing pamphlet with delusions of grandeur. Real sales enablement isn't pretty. It's messy, tactical, and tied to specific moments in real deals: - Marketing Collateral: "Here's our competitive differentiation overview" - Sales Enablement: "When they bring up Epic integration concerns on slide 12, here's exactly what to say and the specific customer story that closes that gap" Marketing Collateral: "Our ROI calculator" Sales Enablement: "When the CFO asks about payback period, show this specific health system's 18-month results, not the generic calculator" Marketing Collateral: "Product feature comparison chart" Sales Enablement: "If they say 'We're already happy with our current solution,' here are the three follow-up questions that uncover hidden dissatisfaction" True enablement is stage-specific, objection-tested, and battle-proven. It's not what sounds good in a conference room - it's what actually works when you're sitting across from a skeptical CMIO who's been burned by three other "revolutionary" solutions. Before you create another slide deck, ask: Has this exact content helped close a real deal? If not, it's marketing. And marketing doesn't belong in your sales process. hashtag # GTM hashtag # salesenablement hashtag # sales hashtag # growth hashtag # growthhacking

Every "no" is free market research. You're just too busy being defensive to listen. When a health system CFO says "We don't have budget for this," most founders hear rejection. I hear intelligence: You're selling to the wrong person at the wrong time with the wrong value proposition. Here's what objections actually tell you about your GTM strategy: "We need to see more ROI data" = Your business case is weak, not your product "Our IT team won't approve this" = You skipped a crucial stakeholder in your process "We're already working with [competitor]" = You're not differentiated enough or entered too late "This isn't a priority right now" = You haven't connected to their urgent pain points Part of my "ninja skill" is helping founders and CEOs of health tech companies treat objections like diagnostic tools. They record every "no," categorize the themes, and reverse-engineer their entire go-to-market strategy from the patterns. Try this: After 20 sales conversations, map your objections by frequency. If 60% are about integration complexity, your product positioning is wrong. If 40% are about ROI uncertainty, your business case needs work. If 30% are about timing, you're not selling urgency effectively. Stop treating objections like obstacles. Start treating them like your market telling you exactly how to win. hashtag # founders hashtag # healthtech hashtag # GTM hashtag # healthcareinnovation

Every health system is drowning in "innovative solutions" that create more work than they eliminate. Your product might be technically superior, but if it requires 15 new clicks in Epic, three additional training sessions, and a workflow change that pisses off nurses, it's dead on arrival. The winners in health tech aren't the ones with the best algorithms - they're the ones who remove the most friction: - Slack reduced communication friction for teams - Zoom eliminated travel friction for meetings - Your health tech solution needs to eliminate process friction for overworked clinicians Before you pitch another feature, ask: 1. Does this make their day easier or harder? 2. Can they use it without changing their existing workflow? 3. Will this solve problems or create new ones? I've seen brilliant AI companies fail because their solution required ED physicians to log into a separate system. Meanwhile, a simpler tool that embedded directly into their existing workflow captured the entire market. Stop building features. Start removing barriers. hashtag # founders hashtag # healthtech hashtag # GTM hashtag # healthcareinnovation The path of least resistance wins every time in healthcare.

Your first slide shouldn't be your company timeline. It should be their nightmare scenario. I've sat through hundreds of health tech pitches that started with "Founded in 2019, we're revolutionizing..." while the CMIO is already checking their phone. You've got 90 seconds before they mentally check out - don't waste it on your origin story. Start with pain. Real, specific, expensive pain: "Last month, your ED had 47 patients leave without being seen. That's $180K in lost revenue, plus the regulatory headache when one of them bounces back sicker. This happens because..." Now you have their attention. Now they're leaning in instead of planning their next meeting. The framework that actually works: 1. Open with their specific problem (with numbers) 2. Show the cascading consequences 3. Present your solution as the logical fix 4. Prove it works with similar health systems Skip the company overview. Skip the market size. Skip everything that isn't directly about solving their immediate problem. Remember: They don't care about your technology until they believe you understand their reality. hashtag # GTM hashtag # outcomes hashtag # valueselling hashtag # salesenablement hashtag # strategicselling

Plot twist: The person who invited you to the meeting probably can't buy anything. I've seen startups burn entire quarters pitching to "innovation champions" who have zero budget authority and negative political capital. Keep in mind: - If they can't sign a contract, they're an influencer, not a buyer - If they need to "run it by" three other people, you're not talking to the right person - If they're excited but can't tell you the procurement process, you're in evaluation hell (I am hearing this is happening A LOT specifically when selling into MA plans as of late). Stop telling yourself that prospect "went dark" because they're busy with patient care or budget season. Be comfortable with the uncomfortable which is your solution isn't urgent enough to matter. When a CMIO stops returning calls, it's not because Epic crashed again. It's because you failed to connect your product to something that keeps them awake at 3 AM. I've watched founders chase ghosts for months, convinced they just need "one more follow-up." Meanwhile, their competitor just closed a deal with the same health system because they led with "We'll cut your readmission penalties by $2.3M this year" instead of "Our AI has 97% accuracy." The fix? Stop pitching features. Start with consequences: 1. What happens if they do nothing? 2. What's the cost of the status quo in dollars, compliance risk, or patient outcomes? 3. Why is solving this problem worth disrupting their already chaotic workflow? If you can't answer those questions in 30 seconds, you don't have a sales problem, you have a value problem. hashtag # GTM hashtag # outcomes hashtag # valueselling hashtag # salesenablement hashtag # strategicselling

Content doesn't have to be all thought leadership and dry "tangible takeaways." You also shouldn't create with the goal of going viral. However, if you are selling B2B, don't just seek inspiration from Linkedin or Reddit threads. We are entering an era where content can be fun, interactive, bold, meaningful, and not always focused on selling... but instead elevating the brand or the people behind the brand. Kudos to the social media team at Hilton Universal | Los Angeles. This video has 2M views on tiktok and it was posted less than 5 days ago. Why am I highlighting this? Sales requires people to know, LIKE and trust you. I think post-covid, people focus too much on the know and trust and forgot about the likability factor. Maybe it's because we went so long without face to face interaction, people have lost interpersonal communication skills or a more provocative thought is people are scared to step outside of their comfort zone in fear of being cancelled. However, this video has nothing to do with the Hilton brand. I see high powered executives having fun, being human, playing into a pop culture trend right now (IYKYK), and this one video just catapulted this one hotel (out of a massive brand) into the next stratosphere. I was expecting the comments section to complain that there are was only one women execs at the table. And as a woman, I was delighted to say that wasn't called out (because negativity like that gets old). Instead, they have brands like Microsoft , Indeed , The Weather Channel , and LIV Golf as well as 1,300 additional comments interacting with one another, calling out who has the best Justin Beiber stomp, who has the most swag, and people saying "I want to stay at this hotel." THAT is the power of content. We are in the era of content whether you like it or not. We consume it multiple times a day and our entire world evolves around it. Stop avoiding it because you dont understand it or havent seen results from it. But also, which stomp on this video was your favorite? (Mine is #2 and im guessing he has Gen Z kids because this wasnt his first Bieber stomp ğŸ¤£ ) Happy Tuesday!

Healthcare Marketers: Words Matter. So Does Targeting. I got served this ad this morning: â€œMedical Centers: Get an AI Front Desk Team for 10% the Cost.â€ A few things jumped out immediately: 1. Medical centers? In U.S. healthcare, that typically means a hospital or large integrated facility. But the ad then says, â€œSee how a practice was able to achieveâ€¦â€ So are we talking hospitals or small outpatient practices? Thatâ€™s a huge difference in buying process, use case, and decision-makers. 2. 90% fewer missed inquiries. Great statâ€”but what does that actually mean? Missed appointment requests? Clinical documentation queries? Patient portal messages? Ambiguity like this erodes trust. 3. 33+ weekly hours saved. Per what? One front desk person? A five-clinic group? The whole IDN? This kind of stat only resonates when itâ€™s grounded in context. 4. Targeting. This was served to me on Instagram. Iâ€™m not a clinician, not a practice manager. So whoâ€™s the buyer? If youâ€™re spending ad dollars, clarity on the objective is essential. When I work with clients on GTM and marketing strategy, this is where we always start: âœ… Who pays for this? âœ… Who uses it? âœ… Who benefits from it? âœ… What language do those people actually use? Then we map messaging from the buyer backward, not from the product forward. If youâ€™re in health tech, this isnâ€™t nitpicking. Itâ€™s survival. The more trust you can build through precision, the faster your path to conversion. Iâ€™m not trying to throw this company under the bus, hence me crossing off the logo. I am startup founders biggest fan, especially if they can improve patient outcomes, reduce provider burnout, lower costs or improve the overall experience. AI Prompts are not IP. I am not sure why its trending on this platform to say "I developed a prompt that does xyz, comment or DM to get access." That is lame and I won't be doing that. I took someone else's solid privacy prompt "promise" or the claimed output and ran it through my own prompt framework to make it actually useful and structured. -TASK -ACTION -ROLE -OUTPUT Now it produces a 17-page privacy risk report in under 1 minute (not 4) â€” covering GDPR, CCPA, consent UX, dark patterns, recent enforcement actions, and a checklist of what to fix. Enjoy (if this is your thing) ğŸ«  "You are a senior privacy compliance analyst with expertise in global data protection regulations, including GDPR, CCPA, and other major privacy frameworks. Perform a full privacy risk assessment of the following website: [INSERT WEBSITE URL]. Your output should mimic the structure and tone of a regulatorâ€™s audit report. Break the report into the following sections: Legal Compliance Overview: Evaluate compliance with GDPR, CCPA, and any other relevant US state laws. Note any gaps or violations. Cookie Consent Models: Analyze the websiteâ€™s cookie banner implementation by geographic region. Specify whether it uses opt-in or opt-out models. Consent UX Audit: Identify UX patterns that reduce transparency or mislead users. Highlight dark patterns like pre-checked boxes or â€œAccept Allâ€ design biases. Risk Contextualization: Reference recent regulatory enforcement actions or fines for similar practices. Remediation Checklist: Provide a plain-language list of specific actions to achieve compliance, mapped directly to the failures above. The report should be clear, thorough, and formatted for executive review (approx. 15â€“20 pages if printed). Write in a formal tone, like an internal audit report prepared for legal or compliance review. Begin by identifying visible data collection mechanisms on the homepage and major user flows." hashtag # AI hashtag # promptengineer hashtag # python

This one has been sitting in my drafts for quite a while.. I fired a client. Not because I couldnâ€™t help. But because they refused to listen. Virtual visits are table stakes 3. Ignoring insurance cuts off 95% of your potential market 4. Building for your own pain points â‰  building for actual market demand Bottom line - If youâ€™re serious about healthcare innovation, solve real problems for real peopleâ€”and do it responsibly. Not all content translates across platforms. I can't believe I am posting this on Linkedin, but yolo. I met with a Tampa business owner last Friday who's looking to revamp their market position and content strategy. His request? "Build me 10 pieces of long-form content that my marketing intern can repurpose across all social media channels. We can just rinse and repeat versus hiring you to rebuild this from the ground up." This is unfortunately not uncommon in my world right now. I get that people don't want to invest in something they don't understand, and thats on me to continuing educating while that mentality is not going to solve your brand awareness problem or increase your incoming leads. While you can absolutely repurpose some content when it makes sense, assuming 10 pieces of "meaty" content will fuel your entire social media engine is fundamentally flawed. Any "AI marketing" agency claiming they can do this without human involvement is either lying or looking for a quick cash grab. This video I'm sharing? It was created for TikTok and intended to show what a "day in the life of a consultant" looks like â€“ even though in reality, this was filmed over 4 days and only captured about 30% of my actual day. It probably doesn't "belong" on LinkedIn by traditional standards, and some of you might be thinking exactly that. But here's why I'm posting it anyway: As someone who doesn't answer to corporate compliance, I believe in testing different content formats, even if they fail. The goal isn't to flood LinkedIn with TikTok dances or political memes, but to understand what resonates where. If you're a business, startup, or professional trying to increase your presence but aren't sure what your niche is â€“ just post it. Test. Learn. Adapt. I'm honestly cringing a bit that this video is now in the LinkedIn universe, but it's authentic, it was fun to create, and it's lighter than my usual "you must have a GTM strategy" content. Don't get me wrong â€“ those 10 pieces of long-form content absolutely have their place, as long as they're written to target your buyers, your end users, your decision makers, and the audience you're trying to engage with. But to assume those 10 pieces are going to provide enough variety to revive your lack of top-of-funnel presence or market visibility? That's completely and utterly false. Sometimes the best way to illustrate that platforms are different is to show exactly what happens when content crosses those boundaries. hashtag # socialmedia hashtag # contentstrategy hashtag # dayinthelife hashtag # marketing

Over the past decade, I've witnessed a concerning shift toward victim mentality in our culture. While I deeply acknowledge that real trauma and genuine hardships exist (Trust me as I have experienced this myself in the last 6 months) and those moments deserve our compassion and support, but if I am being real: Nobody is coming to save you. No rescue boat. No thrown raft. No cavalry charging over the hill. This isn't meant to be harshâ€”it's meant to be liberating. Because if no one else holds the power to save you, then YOU hold that power. You are both the author and the hero of your own story. I've seen too many talented people surrender their agency, waiting for external validation, perfect conditions, or someone else to solve their problems. Meanwhile, others with far greater obstacles choose to be victors, taking ownership, making hard choices, and refusing to let circumstances define them. Yes, life can knock you down. Yes, some people face more challenges than others. But until your final breath, the reset button remains within reach. Every single day offers a chance to choose a different path, to write a different chapter, to become who you're meant to be. Your past doesn't have to be your prison. Your circumstances don't have to be your ceiling. The question isn't whether you'll face adversity because I can guarantee with confidence, you will. The question is: Will you let it make you a victim or forge you into a victor? The choice, as always, is yours. Not my usual content but I actually needed this reminder myself today, so putting into out into the universe as a reminder.

Most B2B pilots end up as expensive science experiments that never see the light of day again. We treat pilots like proof-of-concept when we should be treating them like the opening move in a much bigger game. Before You Even Start the Pilot ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ Map the REAL decision ecosystem. That clinician who loves your solution? They're not writing the check. You need the IT director who'll implement it, the CFO who'll fund it, and the department heads who'll actually use it. One "no" from any of these players kills your expansion dreams. Get expansion commitments upfront. Don't just ask "What does success look like?" Ask "If we hit these metrics, what's the process for rolling this out to the other 47 locations?" Make them walk through their internal expansion process before you deliver a single result. During the Pilot: ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ Create evangelists, not just users. Your pilot users need to become your internal sales force. Give them the data, talking points, and wins they need to sell UP the organization. A passionate department head beats any sales deck. Document everything obsessively. ROI calculations, user testimonials, workflow improvements, time savingsâ€”make it impossible for stakeholders to say "we need more data" when expansion discussions begin. The Expansion Play: ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ Present a roadmap, not just results. Show them exactly how this scales: timeline, resource requirements, change management plan. Remove every possible friction point from their decision-making process. Address the hidden objections. IT will worry about integration complexity. Finance will want clear payback periods. End users will fear workflow disruption. Get ahead of these concerns with specific solutions. The difference between a successful pilot and a successful business? Treating the pilot as the first phase of expansion, not a standalone experiment. hashtag # B2BSales hashtag # Pilots hashtag # Healthcare hashtag # TechSales

Marketing dashboard: ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ Sales dashboard: ğŸ’€ If this is your reality, the problem isn't lead volume. It's everything that happens between "demo request submitted" and "discovery call scheduled." That "ready to buy" lead who downloaded your ROI calculator? They're actually a grad student writing a thesis on your industry. Your lead scoring gave them 90 points because they hit every engagement trigger, but they have zero budget and no authority. Meanwhile, the CFO who spent 30 seconds on your pricing page gets marked as "cold" because they didn't fill out your 12-field form. Sales team: "Marketing only sends us garbage leads." Marketing team: "Sales never follows up properly." Both are probably right. Marketing qualified them based on company size and title. Sales qualified them based on an actual conversation. Turns out the VP of Operations at a 500-person company might not have budget for enterprise software. Lead comes in Tuesday at 2 PM. Sales gets notified Thursday morning. First outreach happens the following Monday. By then, your buyer has already taken three other demos and mentally moved on. Speed to lead isn't just a nice-to-haveâ€”it's often the difference between "first vendor we're considering" and "last vendor we're humoring." Stop measuring marketing on MQLs and sales on activity metrics. Start measuring both teams on revenue influence and pipeline progression. When marketing knows their leads need to actually convert and sales knows they're accountable for working every qualified lead quickly, the finger-pointing stops and the collaboration starts. Also: if your "hot" leads are consistently cold, your scoring model is broken. Fix the inputs, not the math. hashtag # Marketing hashtag # LeadGeneration hashtag # SalesOperations hashtag # B2BMarketing

"We're just waiting on budget approval." Then radio silence for three months. Sound familiar? Here's what actually happened (hint: it wasn't about money) 1. Your champion loved your demo, but when they had to explain it to their boss, they fumbled. They couldn't clearly articulate why this matters NOW or what specifically changes if they don't act. If your buyer can't explain your value in one crisp sentence to someone who wasn't in your meetings, you've lost. Period. 2. Maybe you had great discovery calls in January, but you didn't realize they just committed to a massive ERP implementation that's eating all their bandwidth through end of Q3. Or the new CMO starts next month and wants to review all vendor decisions. Sometimes it's not about your solutionâ€”it's about everything else competing for their attention. 3. The person who brought you in loves your product but carries zero political weight. They can't get time with the decision makers, can't navigate internal politics, and definitely can't push back on "let's revisit this next quarter." You need champions who can fight for you when you're not in the room. I am sorry to tell you this but they didn't ghost you because they ran out of money (even though you told the board that). They ghosted you because: - The problem you solve doesn't feel urgent enough - Your champion couldn't build a compelling internal case - Something bigger and shinier showed up on their priority list I know the budget excuse is just easier than saying "this isn't important enough right now." Next time someone goes dark, ask yourself: did I give them everything they needed to sell this internally? Or did I just assume they'd figure it out? hashtag # B2BSales hashtag # SalesStrategy hashtag # DealManagement hashtag # SalesTraining

Radical responsibility mapping changed my GTM playbook with clients. One owner per outcome-no more excuses. Hereâ€™s the problem I kept seeing: Revenue gaps didnâ€™t come from lazy teams or a missing feature. They came from â€œsystems problemsâ€ - where everyone was busy, but no one truly owned the outcome. I used to think more activity meant better results. But all the calls, demos, and Slack threads didnâ€™t add up. Pipeline kept looking full, but deals stalled. Sound familiar? Same product. Same health system. Two completely different conversations. The Chief Medical Officer: "Show me how this improves patient outcomes and physician workflow." The CEO: "Show me how this impacts our quality scores and bottom line." Most health tech companies use the same pitch for both audiences and wonder why deals stall in committee reviews. Successful healthcare sales require dual-track approaches: 1. The Clinical Playbook: - Lead with patient impact and workflow efficiency - Use clinical evidence and peer testimonials - Address adoption concerns and training requirements - Focus on how it makes their job easier, not just better 2. The Executive Playbook: - Lead with financial outcomes and competitive positioning - Use business case studies and ROI projections - Address implementation timelines and resource requirements - Focus on organizational transformation, not just operational improvement The strategy? Align both tracks toward the same outcome while speaking each stakeholder's language. When the CMO sees improved patient care and the CEO sees improved margins, you get unanimous committee approval instead of internal debates. Takeaway: Don't choose between clinical credibility and business impactâ€”build messaging that delivers both simultaneously to different stakeholders in the same deal. hashtag # GTM hashtag # messaging hashtag # salesplaybook hashtag # startups

I turn 40 next May ğŸ˜ Ten years ago, on my 30th birthday, I sat down and wrote a list of everything I wanted to accomplish in this decade. As I stare at that handwritten paper today, my heart pounds with a mix of pride, grief, sadness and joy. The ride has been an interesting one for sure. My 30s List: 1. Make $1M in one year 2. Have another child 3. Become a "chief" 4. Buy my mom and stepdad a home 5. Pay cash for my son's private school 6. Visit Italy, Ireland, and Greece 7. Get back to my NFL cheerleading weight 8. Stop drinking alcohol 9. Retire my husband 10. Buy a boat The Reality: #1 - I'm closer than I ever imagined possible. Stay tuned. #2 - Endometriosis stole this dream from me. ğŸ˜¥ #3 - âœ… I did it. Not as important as I thought. #4 - Still working toward this. Some dreams take longer than a decade. #5 - âœ… My son's private education is secured. #6 - Anniversary trip booked. Finally. #7 - 10 pounds away, but I've never felt stronger or more at peace in my body. #8 - âœ… Alcohol was a non-negotiable to me after losing my father #9 - Someday... #10 - This year. It's happening this year. Here's what I've learned: People see the promotions, the celebrations, the carefully curated moments we share. What they don't see are the 1 AM planning sessions, the hundreds of "no's" before the one "yes," the nights I cried over what felt like impossible goals... ...or the morning I had to redefine what "having it all" actually means. My late father always hassled me about being a slave to corporate and to find meaning outside of my career. I am still working on that. They don't see you getting back up after every failure, pivoting when life changes your plans, or the quiet moments when you realize success isn't just about checking boxesâ€”it's about who you become while chasing them. So, I have 332 days left in this decade. This isn't just about accountability. This is about showing up authentically in a world that often rewards the highlight reel. This is about admitting that even when you're winning, you're also losing. And that both can be true simultaneously. If you're reading this and feeling behind on your own goalsâ€”you're not alone. We're all just figuring it out as we go. What would you tell your younger self who made it?

"Sell the dream, service the nightmare." A client shared this with me on Friday, and it's a perfect example of the pattern that separates businesses that thrive from those that dive. She's standing at a moment of truth - that inflection point where fear and excitement collide. Her business is exploding with opportunity, but she's carrying the scars from her last company where she learned one of the most expensive lessons in business. In her prior role as a CRO, she destroyed her sales targets - 180% of goal. Leadership was celebrating, investors were smiling, everyone thought they'd cracked the code. But they'd built their success on a foundation of sand. Because while sales was winning, operations was failing. Spectacularly. They had a healthcare product that worked beautifully in sandbox environments. They'd even "turned it on" with a handful of beta clients and gotten results. But - and this is crucial - those beta clients were part of the development process. They were invested partners who would work through bugs, tolerate workarounds, and help troubleshoot when things went sideways. The fatal mistake? Leadership confused beta success with market readiness. When real paying customers started onboarding, the clinical workflows that looked smooth in sandbox became a nightmare. These weren't forgiving beta partners - these were healthcare organizations that expected seamless integration from day one. No patience for bugs. No tolerance for "we'll fix that next week." The result? Angry clients, terminated contracts, clawbacks that wiped out months of commissions for her and her team. Team morale plummeted. The CEO started lashing out. People started quitting before the board said "it's time to cut 15% of the workforce." She watched her financial future get ripped away because leadership made the ultimate strategic error: they confused proof of concept with scalable operations. This is the pattern that's killing businesses across America, especially in healthtech. I'm not here to shame leaders - I'm here to shatter the illusion that beta success equals market readiness. The truth? There are well-known startups in healthtech that made this exact mistake last year. They scaled sales without scaling operations beyond beta. Today, they're staring at 4-6 months of cash runway, fighting for survival. Here's what 74% of high-growth startups refuse to understand: Beta clients will forgive you. Paying customers will fire you. Success leaves clues, and so does failure. My client gets it now. She's building with intention, ensuring every workflow is bulletproof before the first sale. The question isn't whether you'll face this challenge - it's whether you'll learn from others' pain or create your own. What's your strategy for moving from beta success to market-ready operations? Because if you don't have one, you're not building a business - you're building another statistical startup: dead on arrival.

Healthcare doesn't reward the best-built product. It rewards the best-aligned team: clinical, technical, and GTM - the triple threat most startups miss. If your founding team is heavy on engineering and light on lived experience inside hospitals, clinics, or payer orgsâ€¦ you're building something that works in demos but dies in deployment. 90% of health tech startups fail not because their technology is bad, but because they never understood the problem they were solving. Too many teams fall into the same trap: âœ… Brilliant engineers âœ… Polished UI âŒ Zero clinical validation âŒ No strategy for 12-18 month buying cycles âŒ Missing clarity about the workflows or politics they're disrupting âŒ Misunderstanding about who their ICP actually is That last one kills deals before they start. You think you're selling to the CMIO, but the CFO holds the budget. You think the department head is your champion, but the frontline staff can torpedo implementation. You focus on the buyer while ignoring the end users who actually determine adoption. Here's what changes everything: 1ï¸âƒ£ Clinical insight isn't optional - it's foundational. When clinicians are embedded early, you don't just build features. You build workflows that enhance care instead of creating more clicks. You catch the workflow breaks that engineers miss and uncover needs that only surface at 2 AM in the ICU. 2ï¸âƒ£ GTM strategy can't be an afterthought. Healthcare buying isn't B2B - it's B2B2B2B. Your "user" (the nurse) isn't your buyer (IT director) isn't your budget holder (CFO) isn't your champion (CMO). Each has different pain points, decision criteria, and veto power. Map every stakeholder from day one. Identify who can say yes, who can say no, and who influences both. Build parallel relationships. That meeting coordinator you're ignoring? They might be your champion's most trusted advisor. 3ï¸âƒ£ The winning formula: Clinical expertise shapes what you build. Technical excellence makes it scalable. GTM mastery gets it adopted. You can't afford to be great at just one. Healthcare demands all three working in lockstep. hashtag # HealthTech hashtag # GTMStrategy hashtag # ClinicalInsight hashtag # DigitalHealth hashtag # Founders

Why I rarely (if ever) take equity-only contracts from startups. Not because I donâ€™t believe in your mission - but because how equity translates to real value isn't always clear Hereâ€™s the TL;DR math (simplified on purpose): Letâ€™s say you offer me: â€¢ 1% equity in your Series A startup â€¢ Current valuation: $10M On paper, thatâ€™s worth ~$100K today. Sounds great, right? But hereâ€™s the reality: 1ï¸âƒ£ You probably wonâ€™t exit at $1B 2ï¸âƒ£ You will dilute in future rounds (my 1% becomes ~0.75%) 3ï¸âƒ£ Iâ€™m taking 100% of the risk, with no salary in hand 4ï¸âƒ£ That â€œequity paydayâ€ could be 7-10 years out â€” if it happens 5ï¸âƒ£ Iâ€™ll owe taxes when/if I exercise, and thereâ€™s no liquidity until you exit Even if you do exit at $1B, and I do make $7M+... Iâ€™ve traded years of work with no cash flow, no guarantees, and no upside protection. Thatâ€™s not a smart deal. Thatâ€™s a lottery ticket. If you believe in your company enough to offer equity, back it up with a cash component - even if itâ€™s modest. It shows respect for my time and alignment with your commitment. ğŸš¨ And if youâ€™re a consultant reading this? ğŸš¨ Equity can be sweet - in addition to a fair rate. But donâ€™t pay your bills with hypothetical exits. Ask yourself: if this company fails way after your engagement is over, would you be proud of the work and feel compensated fairly for it? Still hearing "no" from VCs? It might not be your idea. It might be how you're approaching the process. Theyâ€™re saying no because your company doesnâ€™t match their thesis. Each fund has a focus: stage, geography, check size, sector (hint: "healthcare" can mean payers, providers, life sciences, digital health, or all of the above). Before you pitch, read what theyâ€™ve written. Study who theyâ€™ve funded. If thereâ€™s no match; donâ€™t force one. 2ï¸âƒ£ You pitched an associate, not a decision-maker. Unless youâ€™re being championed internally by a partner, your deal isn't moving forward. Partners make investment decisions. Everyone else filters. Be respectful of the process, but know who has power in the room. 3ï¸âƒ£ You treated it like a transaction, not a relationship. VCs are placing a bet on you, not just your product. They're risking their reputation, passing on your competitors, and committing years to support you. If they canâ€™t see themselves in your corner through the FDA cycles, hospital procurement delays, and policy shifts - it's a pass. 4ï¸âƒ£ You didnâ€™t de-risk the bet. Healthcare is already hard. If youâ€™re: â€¢ not full-time â€¢ missing clinical or technical expertise â€¢ unclear on reimbursement or go-to-market â€¢ unable to articulate regulatory or policy risks Youâ€™re asking them to take on all the uncertainty. Thatâ€™s not a good trade. 5ï¸âƒ£ Youâ€™re not building a VC-backable business. VCs look for scale. Not just a great product or a few reference sites. They need to believe your model can grow 7x-10x and return the fund. Not every healthcare business needs VC capital - and thatâ€™s okay. 6ï¸âƒ£ Youâ€™re not making them believe. Winning founders are ambitious, coachable, and magnetic. They show up with a clear vision, a repeatable model, and the ability to attract talent, customers, and capital. Healthcare is personal, complex, and political. If you donâ€™t have the conviction to lead a movement, VCs will sense that. This isnâ€™t about chasing validation. Itâ€™s about understanding how the capital markets work so you can play the game strategically, not emotionally. Corporate gaslighting? I hate the term. But Iâ€™ve experienced something close to it and not in big corporate America. I was raised by a single mom who taught me to own my outcomes. Be the victor, not the victim. That mindset shaped how I lead. I donâ€™t sugarcoat, I donâ€™t play politics, and I donâ€™t leave people guessing. I give direct, in-the-moment feedback because I believe in giving people a fair shot to grow, improve, and win. My teams know exactly where they stand, because clarity is a form of respect. Over the past few years, words like â€œtriggeredâ€ and â€œgaslitâ€ have exploded in popularity. And while they started as important ways to name harmful behaviors, I worry theyâ€™ve been overused to the point of losing meaning. But that doesnâ€™t mean the underlying behaviors arenâ€™t real. Iâ€™ve seen them up close - especially in early-stage startups. After working for some incredibly large organizations such as Cerner Corporation and UnitedHealth Group , I expected startups to feel different. And they did. Fast. Flat. Energizing. We moved without red tape. Everyone had a seat at the table. It was intoxicating. But post-COVID, something shifted. A wave of new founders entered the market - often without real-world experience managing people, operating in healthcare, or navigating growth. They had strong networks, strong opinions, and weak leadership instincts. And when things got hard, they didnâ€™t self-reflect. They projected. They blamed experienced leaders instead of learning from them. They rewrote facts to preserve ego. They pushed out the talent doing the real work. Then wondered why everything fell apart. Iâ€™ve seen incredible operators leave, not because they werenâ€™t delivering, but because they were slowly being made to feel like the problem. Itâ€™s not always intentional. Sometimes itâ€™s just fear, inexperience, or unchecked insecurity. But the damage is the same. And this is where VCs and boards need to take ownership. If you see dysfunction creeping in - intervene. You have the tools and resources to bring in coaches, advisors, or experienced operators to help founders grow into the leaders their companies need. Donâ€™t wait until the capital is gone and your best people are too burned out to care. For every three founders who spiral like this, Iâ€™ve worked with seven who are the real deal: collaborative, passionate, humble, and constantly learning. They build incredible companies because theyâ€™re willing to grow themselves first. Startups donâ€™t implode because of market fit alone. They implode when no oneâ€™s willing to call out when leadership is the problem. Healthcare is too complex, and too human, for this cycle to keep repeating. Letâ€™s raise the bar. And stop mistaking dysfunction for startup grit. hashtag # leadership hashtag # startupculture hashtag # founders hashtag # corporateculture hashtag # TGIF

I met with an out of touch health tech founder last week. They told me they need "growth hacking" to hit their user targets. I asked to see their unit economics. They didn't have any. ğŸ¤¨ You can't hack your way out of broken fundamentals. Real Growth Requires Four Systems: â¡ï¸ System 1: Predictable Customer Acquisition Not viral loops or referral programs. Repeatable processes that generate qualified leads consistently. In healthcare, this means content that solves specific problems for specific buyers. â¡ï¸ System 2: Defensible Unit Economics Customer Acquisition Cost under 30% of Annual Contract Value. Customer Lifetime Value 3x higher than acquisition cost. If your math doesn't work at 100 customers, it won't work at 1,000. â¡ï¸ System 3: Retention-Based Growth Healthcare buyers switch vendors reluctantly. Your growth should come from expansion revenue, not constant new customer acquisition. Build systems that grow accounts, not just acquire them. â¡ï¸ System 4: Operational Leverage Each new customer should require proportionally fewer resources to serve. If your team grows linearly with revenue, you're building a consulting business, not a scalable company. The reality is that "Growth hacking" in healthcare means building trust with risk-averse buyers through proven outcomes and predictable processes. No shortcuts. No hacks. A health tech client came to me with a pricing problem. They were charging $50K annually per hospital but revenue was stuck at $2M with 40 customers. 18 months later, they hit $7.2M ARR with the same customer base. The secret wasn't just changing the pricing model - it was proving undeniable value first. We implemented five low-cost, high-impact changes that transformed how customers experienced the product: 1. Comprehensive staff training programs (clinical + administrative teams) 2. We assigned dedicated success managers for white-glove onboarding and ongoing optimization. 3. Monthly benchmark reports showed each hospital exactly how they compared to peers. 4. Quarterly business reviews brought C-suite recommendations directly to decision makers. 5. And 24/7 support with sub-2-hour response times made them feel truly supported. Once customers were seeing measurable results and feeling the premium experience, we aligned our pricing to the value we were creating. Then We Restructured Pricing: ğŸš¨ Old Model: Fixed $50K fee (seen as cost center) ğŸ“ˆ New Model: Outcome-based tiers 1. Foundation: $30K base + 15% of documented savings 2. Growth: $40K base + 20% of savings + performance bonuses 3. Partnership: $50K base + 25% of savings + revenue share The psychology shift was everything: customers stopped asking "What does this cost?" and started asking "How much are we making together?" The results: âœ… Average contract value: $50K â†’ $180K âœ…Customer lifetime value increased 340% âœ… Churn dropped to 3% (customers making money don't leave) The lesson? Don't lead with price - lead with proof. When customers can see and measure the value you're creating, they'll gladly pay for more of it. We built a healthcare system that prioritizes sick care over prevention, buried hospitals in regulatory red tape, then act surprised when they charge 1,000% markups to survive. But is "survival" really what's happening here? â Regulatory Burden: The ACA brought meaningful use requirements and compliance layers that consume massive administrative resources. Hospitals claim these justify the markups. â The Medicare Squeeze: Medicare reimbursements often don't cover procedure costs, forcing hospitals to make up losses through private insurance markups. â Prevention Paradox: We spend $4.3 trillion on sick care but only $77 billion on prevention, perpetuating expensive emergency interventions. â Survival Mode: Hospitals say they're caught between government underpayment and escalating regulatory costsâ€”these markups keep doors open. â Profit Extraction: Data shows hospitals charge Medicare only 6% above costs but mark up private insurance 300%+. Same hospital, same drug, massive difference. When hospitals charge $55,000 for a cancer drug like Neulasta that costs around $4,000 at average sales price, we're witnessing the breakdown of healthcare's social contract. Every dollar extracted through excessive markups could fund preventative care, reduce administrative burden, or improve patient outcomes. But would the hospitals be able to keep their doors open? The triple aim won't matter if we don't have a physical place for providers to care for patients. How do we keep hospital doors open without crushing the patients in the process? hashtag # Healthcare hashtag # HospitalPricing hashtag # HealthPolicy hashtag # PreventiveCare hashtag # HealthcareReform

ğŸš¨ Florida just became the first state to issue subpoenas over hospital price transparency. ğŸš¨ On May 31, 2025, Attorney General James Uthmeier launched formal investigations into multiple Florida hospital systems. Despite federal and state laws requiring hospitals to disclose pricing, many facilities continue operating with opaque billing practices that leave patients guessing about costs until after treatment. "Can you walk me through your pitch deck real quick?" I recently heard a health system CTO ask this during a 30-minute intro call with a founder who's gearing up for their Series A. What followed was a painful 47-slide deck. By slide 12, the CTO's eyes had glazed over. Meeting over. If you can't explain your value in 5 slides, you don't understand it yourself. And if you don't understand it, neither will potential buyers or, more importantly, Series A investors. Healthcare buyers are drowning in vendor pitches. They have 15 minutes of attention, not 50. Your job isn't to tell them everything; it's to tell them enough to want more. This applies equally to your sales pitch and your investor pitch. Here's the 5-slide framework that actually works, both for sales and for laying the groundwork for a compelling investor narrative: Slide 1: The Problem. One specific, expensive problem your buyer (or the market) loses sleep over. Slide 2: The Impact. What happens if they don't solve it (costs, risks, missed opportunities). Slide 3: The Solution. How you solve it differently (your unique approach, not just a list of features). Slide 4: The Proof. One powerful customer story with specific outcomes or compelling market validation. Slide 5: The Next Step. Clear, specific next action (a deeper dive, a pilot, an ROI discussion, or an investor follow-up). That's it. No lengthy company overview. No feature laundry list. No 20-minute product demo. Just laser focus on their problem and your solution. The founder I was working with, who's now refining her pitch for Series A, rebuilt her sales and investor narratives using this exact framework. The result for her sales team? 3x more second meetings and 40% faster deal velocity. That's the kind of traction investors want to see. Less really is more. hashtag # pitchperfect hashtag # gtm hashtag # founders hashtag # healthtech hashtag # startups

After years building go-to-market strategies for health tech startups and advising hospitals, I thought I understood healthcare pretty well. Then I became the patient fighting for a diagnosis while managing stage 4 endometriosis. I became the family member watching loved ones suffer not just from illness, but from care coordination failures and insurance battles that turned medical treatment into additional trauma. The view from the hospital bed taught me that all my industry expertise meant nothing when I was the one trying to decode someone else's medical bills, navigate prior authorizations, and advocate for family members in a system that seemed designed to exhaust us into giving up. These experiences didn't break my faith in healthcare innovation. They showed me exactly where my expertise was needed most. So I'm launching The Patient Advocate... This will be a weekly newsletter that translates the deliberately confusing parts of healthcare into language real people can actually use. I'm not abandoning my work in healthcare strategy, go-to-market, or growth. But as part of my own healing process navigating grief, loss, and managing chronic pain, I need to do this work. Advocacy has become essential to how I process what I've experienced and find meaning in what I've learned. Every week I'll break down medical billing tactics, insurance denial strategies, care coordination gaps, and policy changes that directly impact your family's health and financial security. I've seen healthcare from the boardroom and from the hospital bed. I know what the system promises and what patients actually experience. And I'm done watching that gap destroy families. Healthcare is personal. And patients deserve someone in their corner who knows how the game is really played. First issue dropped tonight. The adoption curve in action: -Innovators (2.5%): Building AI-first companies -Early Adopters (13.5%): Integrating AI into workflows, gaining advantages -Early Majority (34%): Experimenting cautiously -Late Majority (34%): Still evaluating -Laggards (16%): In denial about AI's impact Here's the uncomfortable truth: By the time the Early Majority acts, Early Adopters will have captured disproportionate market share. Consider the parallels: 1/Companies that embraced the internet early (Amazon, eBay) defined entire categories 2/Businesses that dismissed e-commerce spent decades playing catch-up 3/The same pattern repeated with mobile and cloud computing What makes AI different is velocity. Companies using AI are not only improving efficiency but also reshaping their value propositions, creating capabilities that non-AI competitors cannot match. The artisans who dismissed factories, the retailers who ignored e-commerceâ€”they all believed they had more time. They were wrong. I don't really know how to write this post so here it goes. On Friday, April 4th, 2025, my biological father committed suicide. I know its not PC to use the words "committed" but I want to be clear that when a person does this, they committed to it and that has a rippling effect that not only impacts their next of kin but their community, their friends, and extended family. It was a commitment to end his physical suffering. It was a commitment to end his own personal demons. And it was a commitment to leave this world on his own terms. I know the days, weeks and months ahead will lead to more questions than answers but I feel compelled to say: You are enough. You matter. There are resources available. And even if you don't know me, I will listen if you need to speak to someone or get you in touch with a specialist. I am sharing with my network because I think we as humans, need to give people more grace. You never know what a person may have weighing on their shoulders, torturing their soul or dealing with professionally and personally. While I was already a patient advocate, I now want to add suicide awareness as well as part of something I will be extremely vocal on. Remember the 3 C's: Connection, Collaboration, and Choice. -Connection implies that the person in crisis is made to feel understood and not isolated -Collaboration involves working collaboratively with the individual to investigate and identify potential solutions -Choice involves empowering the individual by involving them in the decision-making process for their care and recovery Thank you to everyone that has reached out to me the last couple of days. When a company is growing, hitting its numbers, and riding high, everyone is having fun. Team happy hours, leadership town halls, and company all-hands meetings are full of optimism. But when you start missing goals - quarter after quarter - that energy shifts. Leadership starts pointing fingers. Teams go into survival mode. I donâ€™t think we talk about this enough, especially in the world of healthcare sales, where the market dynamics are fundamentally different from selling into other industries. Half the leadership teams donâ€™t fully understand the nuance and length of selling into healthcare, which means they mismanage their teams, set unrealistic expectations, and blame the wrong factors when deals stall. The other half do understand the nuanceâ€”but they spend the majority of their time fighting for airtime, struggling to gain buy-in for a strategy they know would work. Yesterday, I heard something in an interview on Squawk Box that really made me think about some of my past experiences working in corporate as a W-2 employee... Ask mid-level managers what theyâ€™re working on and how it aligns with the companyâ€™s goals for the year. If they donâ€™t know - or worse, if they havenâ€™t even been given the company goals, youâ€™ve got a big problem at the top. Oftentimes, this is an arbitrary exercise led by HR through tools like Lattice - but its ultimately the VP levels and above that are responsible to ensure every role underneath them has clear alignment to their job responsibilities and how their day to day work is contributing to the larger picture. The reality is some leaders have a vision, but they canâ€™t sell it. They hire people to execute their vision but fail to provide a strategy. Teams running on tactics alone, hoping the vision will someday materialize. I have seen it so many times and continue to ponder how these people continue to stay in positions of leadership when they have no real roadmap for their own company, let alone people. Dare I say some of these "leaders" that carry a c-suite title may have a shiny pedigree and a way with the BOD, but to their own people? Their own teams? They are uninspiring, disconnected and likely cant tell you what most people do at their company. They surround themselves with talented people but provide no direction beyond lofty ambitions. The team is left scrambling, relying on individual tactics with no clear path to execution. And hope, as we know, is not a strategy. It's rare but good leadership does exist. - A strong leader has a visionâ€”but also knows they need people to build the strategy that brings it to life. AND they provide direction on how to go execute it. - That strategy then informs tactical execution, ensuring every task at every level contributes to the broader goal. - Without strategy, teams are left doing busywork, checking boxes, and spinning their wheelsâ€”leading to disengagement and burnout. The real problem? When people arenâ€™t given purposeful work, it drains the culture. Whether youâ€™re an analyst or a VP, you want to feel valuable. You want to know your work is contributing to something greater. Leaders who fail to connect vision with execution arenâ€™t just slowing progressâ€”theyâ€™re failing their teams. So, hereâ€™s my question: If I asked your team today what theyâ€™re working on and how it connects to company goals, would they have a clear answer? If not, you have some work to do. hashtag # leadership hashtag # corporateculture hashtag # culture hashtag # hopeisnotastrategy

As of January 1, Medicare reduced physician payments by nearly 3%, marking the third consecutive annual cut since 2020. This reduction, driven by the need to maintain budget neutrality, has left many physicians struggling to balance rising practice costs with declining reimbursements. A critical issue to highlight is the long-term impact of these cuts. According to the American Medical Association , when adjusted for inflation, Medicare reimbursement for physician services has declined a staggering 33% from 2001 to 2025. This decline underscores the growing financial strain on physicians, who are increasingly challenged to provide quality care amidst shrinking resources. Hereâ€™s what you need to know about the 2025 Medicare pay cuts and the ongoing legislative efforts to address them: 1ï¸âƒ£ The 2.83% cut is the third consecutive annual reduction. When adjusted for inflation, this equates to a 6.3% real pay reduction for physicians in 2025. 2ï¸âƒ£ Physician pay has barely increased over the past two decades. Since 2001, Medicare reimbursements have risen just 9% â€” an average of 0.4% per year â€” while the cost of running a medical practice has surged by 59%. 3ï¸âƒ£ The impact will be most severe for small, independent, and rural practices. These cuts also disproportionately affect providers serving low-income and marginalized communities. 4ï¸âƒ£ The cuts are tied to expiring temporary measures and a freeze on inflation updates. A temporary 2.93% payment adjustment expired at the end of 2024, and the Medicare Access and CHIP Reauthorization Act froze fee schedule inflation updates until 2026. There is some hope on the horizon. A bipartisan group of lawmakers recently reintroduced a bill aimed at reversing the 2025 cuts and providing much-needed stability for physician practices. Read the Press Release here: https://lnkd.in/eFgNt9yP The proposed legislation includes a 2% pay bump, along with a 4.73% increase tied to inflation, using the Medicare Economic Index as a benchmark. If passed, the â€œMedicare Patient Access and Practice Stabilization Actâ€ would retroactively address the cuts from January 1 through March 31 and provide a 6.62% payment increase for the remainder of the year. Many organizations, including the American Medical Association (AMA), have voiced strong support for this legislation. AMA President Dr. Bruce Scott emphasized that Medicare payments, when adjusted for inflation, have fallen 33% over the past two decades, leaving physicians struggling to care for an aging and chronically ill population. hashtag # medicare hashtag # policy hashtag # advocacy hashtag # healthcare hashtag # inflation

Letâ€™s talk about TikTok. Love it or hate it, its influence is undeniable. The algorithm? Arguably unmatched. TikTok, by contrast, prioritizes discovery, creativity, and authenticityâ€”qualities that have made it a favorite for users and businesses alike. So, why the push to ban TikTok? Together, they hold between $29 million and $126 million in these stocks. Nancy Pelosi alone owns 5,000 shares of Meta. This isnâ€™t about national securityâ€”itâ€™s about crushing competition. The consequences? Banning TikTok wonâ€™t fix data privacy or misinformation. It will, however, hurt millions of creators, small businesses, and the economy. This platform is more than an app; itâ€™s a cultural and economic movement. Thatâ€™s why, as of this weekend, Iâ€™m deactivating my Meta and X accounts. My small but mighty TikTok account has generated a solid income for me on the side with millions of views just in the last year. TikTok represents a new era of connection, creativity, and opportunity. Movements like this donâ€™t fade... This will change how the 180 million vote in the primary and reaffirm our distrust in the government. hashtag # TikTok hashtag # SocialMedia hashtag # SmallBusiness hashtag # Creators hashtag # DataPrivacy hashtag # Innovation hashtag # FollowTheMoney
