While I no longer work with pre-seed or seed companies outside of fractional work.. I wanted to share an AI prompt specifically for founders. Founders often wear multiple hatsâ€”CEO, marketing, sales, RevOps, and sales enablementâ€”all at once. In industries like healthcare, this becomes even more complex. Healthcare founders face unique challenges: â¡ï¸ Multiple buyers: Clinical, financial, operations, and administration all play a role in the decision-making process. â¡ï¸ Long sales cycles: Educating stakeholders and gaining approval for adoption can take months. â¡ï¸ Integration hurdles: Your solution must seamlessly fit into existing workflows. Hiring a VP of Sales without first mapping out these components can set both the hire and the company up for failure. Before bringing in a sales leader, founders need to establish a clear understanding of their sales process, goals, and metrics. To help founders navigate this complexity, hereâ€™s an AI prompt you can use to build a solid sales foundation: â€œAct as a sales strategy consultant. Provide a clear and actionable plan for establishing sales goals and performance metrics for a department. Include steps to: Analyze current performance and past trends. (Our ACV is currently $XXX,XXX) and our sales cycle is currently take anywhere from (X months to X months) Set realistic and achievable sales goals aligned with the companyâ€™s overall objectives (Our committed revenue goal for 2025 is $X,XXX,XXX) Identify key performance indicators (KPIs) such as revenue, profit margins, customer satisfaction, and market share. (We have committed to the following margin goal to our board members and investors (XX% Margins) Recommend tools and resources (e.g., sales tracking software, performance dashboards) to track and evaluate success. Tailor this plan for a healthcare startup with multiple buyers (clinical, financial, operations, administration), a long sales cycle, and the need for stakeholder education and workflow integration.â€ This prompt can help you create a data-driven sales strategy that accounts for the unique challenges of your industry and sets your team up for success. This is not meant to be your sales playbook, that will be built in additional prompts after this one ğŸ˜‰ Let me know if this helps and if you are interested in more! hashtag # salesstrategy hashtag # founders hashtag # healthcaretech hashtag # salesplaybook hashtag # ai

My post last week caused quite a bit of debate and I want to double down on my position.... UnitedHealthcare's 2025 GLP-1 exclusion exposes both short-sighted economics and deeper systemic failures. Let's break down what's really happening and the math they are intentionally ignoring: Obesity drives our costliest chronic conditions: - Type 2 Diabetes: $327B yearly - Heart Failure: $30B yearly - COPD: $50B yearly When we have effective treatments for obesity, denying access isn't cost controlâ€”it's cost deferral. Here's what's really at stake: â¡ï¸ Narrow Clinical Pathways: Insurance companies are redefining 'medical necessity' to exclude obesity treatment, even as research shows these medications reduce heart disease, improve sleep apnea, and lower joint stress. They're creating a false divide between treating diabetes and treating obesity. â¡ï¸ The Real Cost Equation: Yes, GLP-1s are expensive. But insurers aren't publicly discussing the long-term savings from preventing diabetes complications, reducing joint replacements, and improving cardiovascular outcomes. Short-term thinking is driving long-term costs. â¡ï¸ Access Inequity: The 'pay cash' workaround means only affluent patients can access these medications consistently. We're creating a two-tier system where proven medical treatments are available based on wealth, not medical need. The Path Forward: 1. Value-based contracts that tie drug pricing to patient outcomes 2. Smart coverage criteria that supports comprehensive treatment plans 3. Integrated programs that combine medication with lifestyle support We're not choosing between covering or not covering GLP-1s. We're choosing between reducing obesity prevalence now or costly complications later. Question for healthcare leaders: How do we break this cycle of short-term cost cutting that drives long-term health inequities? hashtag # HealthcareInnovation hashtag # HealthEquity hashtag # ValueBasedCare hashtag # PreventiveCare "

You know that feeling when you read something and think "No way a real person wrote this"? Let's get real for a second - we all see those LinkedIn accounts pumping out post after post, 24/7. Add in some AI magic and auto-scheduling tools like Taplio, and suddenly you're a "thought leader" posting deep insights at 3 AM. Sound familiar? Yeah, I might know a thing or two about that game. ğŸ˜‰ But here's the thing - people aren't dumb and neither is the algorithm. Both can tell when they're reading recycled ideas that have been run through an AI blender. Real content hits different. It makes you stop scrolling. Makes you think. Maybe even makes you laugh or roll your eyes. Don't get me wrong - AI is awesome for getting stuff done fast. But when everyone's using the same tools to scrape the same content and post at the same times... well, your feed starts looking like a bunch of robots talking to each other. Trust me, once you see the pattern, you can't unsee it.

I appreciate all of the provocative opinions and comments on the threads this past week as we start to have actual dialogue that the US healthcare system is beyond messed up. Two things can be true at the same time: A. I donâ€™t believe (today) in a federally managed universal healthcare system And B. I believe if we are going to pay the exorbitant amount of taxes that we do, I would like to see basic healthcare options provided to all tax paying Americans such as annual wellness visits, non emergency services and access to telehealth visits for my rural communities. But Brett, that is universal healthcare. ğŸ§ Youâ€™re right, it isâ€¦. (Or a version of it) Here is my issue that seems to be lost by many: Medicare is set to become insolvent (once again) by 2036. Social security will become insolvent by 2033. When my grandfather was recently discharged from the hospital (a retired Air Force Major) the wait list to get him into a VA skilled nursing facility was 6-8 weeksâ€¦. Which he did not have that much time left so we were forced to move him to a rehab facility and pay out of pocket for it due to him being ineligible for that facility because he was on warfarin. Show me a federal government that is capable of balancing a budget, providing transparency to the American people. Show me a federal run agency that can pass an annual audit (not fail their 6th) and being unable to account for all of its $3.8 trillion in assets and $4 trillion in liabilities. Show me a federal program that is not heavily persuaded by lobbyist (specifically pharmaceutical companies) when it comes to what policies they push. At this point, take the insurance companies out of it completely and let me pay for concierge primary care and negotiate directly with hospitals for my upcoming surgery. Itâ€™s frusterating on this platform that itâ€™s either â€œall inâ€ on universal or burn the whole system down. I hate insurance companies and I say that as a former Optum employee. They dictate what medications my husband or I should be allowed to take, they deny coverage despite lengthy and highly burdensome pre authorization processes. But letâ€™s not forget that CMS continues to enable the bad behavior with bad policy, inept leadership, misaligned incentives for value based care and politicians who know nothing about healthcare policy running the show. There is not one single enemy here - there are hundreds if not thousands of bad actorsâ€¦. â€¦. and no they are not clinicians, coders, or even hospital or regional plan administrators - they are just trying to survive and stay open for business to serve their patientsâ€¦ being asked to do more with less, year over year.

Ok Iâ€™m just throwing this out thereâ€¦. Ready for attacks, eye rolls and debatesâ€¦ In 2023, the UK spent Â£292 billion (10.9% GDP) on healthcare, averaging Â£4,358 ($5,552) per person. Compare that to the US in 2022: 17.3% GDP, or $13,493 (Â£10,589) per person. Wild, right? It should be noted that the population im referring to based on the UK figures is only 67m and their marginal tax rate is 60% ğŸ¤¡ In comparison, the US population is 330m with taxes ranging anywhere from 3.2% (lowest 20%) up to 37% (top 1%). However, what surprised me was that the UKâ€™s universal healthcare covers primary care, hospital services, maternity, mental health, community health, ambulance services, and prescribed medicationsâ€”but 20% of residents also pay for private insurance. Why? To avoid long waits, choose their doctors, or access services not covered by the NHS. Their system isnâ€™t perfectly equal, but I could see where diplomacy at our confessional level could find middle ground somewhere in there. Healthcare isnâ€™t one-size-fits-all; chronic illnesses like my endometriosis show how needs vary by age, race, genetics, and more. What the US needs is a shift from reactive care to prevention. We are currently a system (intentionally) built to treat the symptoms, keeping us sick and reacting to disease versus mitigating it. Imagine the savings we could achieve if every American had access to an annual wellness visit through a universal plan, reducing ED visits and improving overall health. If I had more confidence that our government wasn't completely corrupt from the top down, I would be happy to pay for high taxes to go towards a similar structure, under the assumption that you would be required to have an annual wellness visit as part of that plan... in addition, we need to incentivize more people to go into the business of medicine meaning medical school and nursing school should be subsidized in some way shape or form (havent figured that one out yet). In order to make a system like this work, with our large geography and population, we need more clinicians, more automation (more AI), and wild transparency about the cost of prescriptions. No more price gouging, no more payer dictating which medications they will "allow," no more pharma advertising their drugs on TV and no more pharma lobbyist on capital hill or in bed with food manufactures/farmers. Hope this helps or at least is the beginning of productive conversations about we change the direction of our healthcare ecosystem going forward.

The recent debate on my healthcare post stating universal healthcare is not the dystopian answer we need. Let me be clear, my skepticism about universal healthcare isn't rooted in opposition to access, but in the track record of policy implementation. Take the ACA's results since 2010: -Family premiums rose 74% (22% after inflation adjustment) -Many lost existing plans despite contrary promises -Independent practices consolidated, reducing competition -Drug prices doubled while congressional stockholders profited With Medicare facing insolvency by 2031 and current programs struggling with transparency and fiscal responsibility, why trust the same system with universal healthcare? Meanwhile, private insurers have overstepped their role. Instead of focusing on risk management and policyholder protection, they're dictating care, creating narrow networks, and implementing arbitrary claim denials. Real reform needs to prioritize patient care and transparency â€“ both in government programs and private insurance. Until then, I remain skeptical of expanding a system that's already showing serious cracks. hashtag # HealthcareReform hashtag # HealthPolicy hashtag # Healthcare

Imagine this: Your provider has meticulously documented your medical necessity for a prescribed medication. Theyâ€™ve jumped through the hoops, spent precious time submitting a prior authorization (PA), and stillâ€”itâ€™s denied. The insurance company, not a doctor, decides your health doesnâ€™t warrant the treatment. Now, itâ€™s not just medications. Insurance companies are increasingly inserting themselves into clinical decisions they are unqualified to make. Take, for example, the recent uproar over new anesthesia time limits set by Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield Providers are sounding the alarm, because these arbitrary limits prioritize cost savings over patient safety. When I had my hysterectomy last year, my anesthesia alone was billed at $39,798? I had complications once they got in there, so was under for almost an hour longer than anticipated. So, Anthem expects me to pick up that bill now? Why are non-clinicians deciding how much anesthesia a patient needs? This trend is alarming. It erodes trust, delays care, and forces providers to fight for their patients instead of focusing on treatment. It begs the question: When did insurers become the gatekeepers of care, overriding the judgment of licensed providers who know us best? We need more transparency, advocacy, and accountability. The insurance tail shouldnâ€™t wag the healthcare dog. I am all for identifying and mitigating waste, fraud and abuse but I am having a hard time wrapping my head around why a surgeon or anesthesiologists would intentionally keep a patient under longer than they have too - unless it was medically necessary. Better yet, this is the sword Anthem wants to fall on?

14 Years of ACA: Are We Better Off? Fourteen years later, the data tells a different story. â¡ï¸ Healthcare spending remains as concentrated as ever. In 2010, the top 5% of healthcare spenders accounted for 50% of total spending. In 2023, that figure hasnâ€™t budged. Meanwhile, the bottom 50% of Americansâ€”those least able to afford careâ€”still account for less than 3% of the total spend. â¡ï¸ The cycle of sickness and profit continues. Our system is in purgatory: âŒ We feed people foods that make them sickâ€”even those who â€œeat healthyâ€ under outdated guidelines like the food pyramid. âŒ We treat symptoms with medications that often come with devastating side effects, many of which arenâ€™t covered by insurance. âŒ We fail to prioritize primary care, reducing their Medicare payment per relative value unit, decreasing by 2.83% from 2024 to 2025, the frontline of preventative medicine, where investment could save lives. â¡ï¸ Corruption runs deep. âŒ The ties between Big Food, Big Pharma, government, for-profit, and academic health systems are choking our nationâ€™s health. With the recent appointment of RFK Jr., critics will undoubtedly push back. But ask yourselfâ€”what solutions have been delivered? What progress has been made? Imagine this: the average cost for a one-month stay in a skilled nursing facility is now $8,000 - $10,000. Yes, thatâ€™s for just one month of care. Medicare may cover short-term stays under specific conditions, but long-term costs often fall to personal funds or Medicaid if eligible. Now consider that many Americans need this level of care for months, if not years, due to chronic conditions, age-related decline, or unexpected accidents. How are American families expected to shoulder this burden? With Social Security set to be insolvent by 2035 and Medicare facing the same fate by 2036, the safety net so many people depend on will likely be a shadow of what it once was. Families are left to choose between bankrupting themselves or sacrificing the quality of care for their loved ones. We need to ask ourselves, how did it come to this, and what can we do to fix it? The conversation needs to shift from treating these costs as â€˜just the way it isâ€™ to demanding real solutions for sustainable elder care in America. Is it time to rethink our priorities?

ğŸš¨This might be a hot take for a Saturday morning but itâ€™s been bothering me as I research acquired or failed startups that tried to impact either care coordination or anything relating to the post-acute healthcare ecosystemâ€¦. I think weâ€™ll come to view the last few decades in health tech as a missed opportunity. Why? Because the venture capital worldâ€™s rapid-fire expectations for growth doesnâ€™t align with the long, complex timelines required for meaningful progress in healthcare. In the rush to capture market share, we saw an explosion of health tech startups, but at what cost? Instead of solving the industryâ€™s most pressing issues, the influx of well-funded companies often cluttered the landscape with more intricate workflows, fragmented credentialing processes, and very few universally applied standards of care. For years, it felt like a gold rushâ€”a mad dash to build the â€œnext big thingâ€ and secure the next funding round. But in that sprint for financial gain, weâ€™ve lost sight of the end user: patients and practitioners who need reliable, integrated solutions. The health tech sector isnâ€™t like other tech industries; growth here isnâ€™t just about speed or scaleâ€”itâ€™s about sustained, measurable improvements in patient outcomes and workflow efficiencies for healthcare providers. So where does this leave us now? Saddled with disconnected tools and an industry overwhelmed by a flood of shiny solutions, all vying for a slice of the same pie. And sadly, too many promising ideas fell by the wayside, not because they werenâ€™t valuable, but because they couldnâ€™t fit the â€œgrow fast or dieâ€ mantra. The question is: Will we take this lesson forward? Or will the pursuit of quick returns continue to stifle true innovation in healthcare for decades to come?
